content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								My first StarMade Experience: 1st-2nd hours:I get on the server (redshift). I am so damn overwhelmed by the cool spawn and spaceships docked there. I have no idea of what to do, so I request help from a fellow player. One thing leads to another, and I am now in this guy's faction. its just the guy, his friend, and me. He surprisingly has about six ships, 2 for mining, one with a jump drive, a few fighters, and some other huge ship with unknown purpose,also a space station orbiting a terraformed planet. Guy teaches me the basics, and then logs off. You can not blame me for wanting to try out the stuff. First I try building my own ship, a core, a power supply and a thruster, and I realize the ship is simple and fast. I land on the planet. I forget to press shift. ship flies off even with me getting out of it. I'm stranded in the planet. SHEEEEIIIIT. I start mining blocks, and build a pilar trying to reach the space station. I am successful, and get back on. 3rd Hour:I now am familiar with the basic controls of the game (I took a while to get used to the controls of this one). I am curious, so I decide to take the warpship for a spin. The jumpdrive jumps about 8 sectors per jump. I start charging and jumping all over the universe,the setting is relaxed, I'm listening to some slow trance,and I am actually having a lot of fun exploring. Suddenly I see another station. "I should dock there" I thought. As I arrive near the foreign station my systems begin to fail, and I start getting blasted. I mean BLASTED by lazers and projectiles of all sorts. The ship is dead. THE SHIP IS ♥♥♥♥ING DEAD!!! THE GUY IS GONNA KILL ME!!!!!! How would I look him in the eyes, the one person who helped me out, who took me under his wing, I was ashamed. I managed to find my way back to my faction's station, and about half hour later the faction leader who took me in logged on. oshitoshitoshitoshitosheeit. First thing he asks me: "hey man, have you seen the jumpship, you know the one that looks kind of like a satellite?" "Y-yes I s-s-aw s-someone stealing it". He looked at me, then he kicked me out of the faction, and blew me back to spawn.10/10 would steal a jumpship and lie about it again

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								On my daily game browsing, I was looking for anything interesting. I came across this game. This is one of the coolest games I have ever played. Some people say this is a Space Engineers clone...it is not. And I am sure (Idk who or why) someone has called this a Minecraft clone...GOD no. (It's in space, come on now.) I will break this up into different sections, with a TL;DR at the end, as well as a section for those who read the whole thing! Thank you.ONE MORE THING: The demo unlocks the whole game for free. The developer said it will stay that way until it goes out of early access, and that buying it is mainly just to support development.Why it is awesome:1. Customization. You can build any kind of ship you want. A ship for transporting things, a ship for mining, a fighter, a massive battle ship, a mining ship with salvage beams (Those are beams that mine for you. SO you shoot at something, it being an ore, rock, or even parts of another ship or station) or any combination of all. (This is not all, of course)2. Fighting. The fighting is incredible and fun, and fast paced action. It is like a Star Wars battle. You can have your fleet of 20 ships versus another player's fleet of 20 ships or against Space Pirates, or in single player, you versus a bunch of pirates (Idk yet if you can have computer controlled fighting allies in singleplayer) The complex weapons systems are for a whole other part of the review.3. The complex weapons systems. There is the basic cannons, lasers, and missiles, and they are fun and damaging. You can make the cannons and any other weapon touch each other to make 1 very damaging weapon, or you can space them out to have many of that weapon firing at once. Here is where it gets complex. You can combine weapons. *SPOILER HERE* So you can combine the cannon and the missile to make a shotgun like weapon on your ship. *SPOILER END* Cool right? And there are over 80 combinations (so I have read). So lots of fun to be had with weapons. (And don't be afraid to stack them up a ton. If you have the weapons available, and the power available, make some crazy weapons systems.)4. NPCs. This is where Space Engineers is lacking so far, but will have them in the future. There are, like I said, Space Pirates. They have killed me many times. But if you have the power and the numbers, fight them back and steal from them and you shall be granted rich reward...so I assume. There are also NPCs at some shops.5. Shops. You can go to a shop and buy anything in the game. You need a lot of money for many things, but you can get a lot of money fairly easy with the right knowledge of what is really valuable, like ores and glass. (More fun with shops later in the review)6 Space Stations. You can do a lot of the same stuff with stations that you can do with ships. I am not sure what it has weapons wise, but I am sure there are good things with that. I know there are turrets. Automated turrets and controllable I think. Very customizable. To make a space station though, you need 1,000,000 credits. Which tbh, isn't that bad. I saw one guy get like 2 million credits from selling a bunch of salvaged (collected) glass. And with a faction you can claim a station as yours and make it invulnerable to damage and stealing. It also makes any docked ships invulnerable too. So griefers aren't a problem with this HAHA! 7. Factions. You can make a faction and build on faction points with players to join it (Idk if npcs can join or not), taking over sectors and systems, defeating enemies, and so on. With a faction you can claim a space station and make it invulnerable to damage and stealing. And you can claim a whole system as your territory. Again, there are 128 x 128 x 128 (I think) sectors in a system, so that is a TON of space as yours. With a faction, you can also make your own shops! You can price items how you want, decide what is on your market, and sell things to other players, and maybe even npcs. (You may not need a faction, you may only need a space station to make a shop. I can't remember) And with a faction you can keep growing your territory until you take over everything MUAHAHAHAHAHHAHA! (Not even kidding though)8. Build mode/Advanced build mode. Who doesn't love a good build mode for easy ship/station construction? With regular build mode you can do all the basic stuff like placing/deleting blocks, flying, sped up flying, connecting blocks and groups, and all that stuff. With advanced build mode, you can use symmetry (For precise building), copy/pasting/saving pieces of ships or stations as templates, mass building with placing up to 10 blocks in every axis at a time (So you can build a 10 x 10 x 10 cube with one click), rotating blocks, and a few other things. So very fun and easy to use. Makes for easy building of a massive ship.9. Jump drives/Warp gates. *SPOILER HERE* The jump drives and warp gates are a great way to get around fast, but you need alot of power. With a jump drive, you can "jump" up to 8 sectors away. With warp gates, (I think) you can warp up to 128 sectors away. So very convenient.10. Asteroids, planets, stars, stations. These are all procedurally generated. Very cool.Now, for the cons. However, some of these are personal opinions and may not matter to you.1. *PERSONAL OPINION* This game has blocks, not voxels. Sometimes I prefer voxels instead of blocks because realistic smooth surface terrain is cool, but it is not a big deal, this game is still great.2. Memory issues. I have noticed a lot of people having memory issues where it gets very laggy and a message pops up in game and says you are running low on memory, and to increase the max and min memory in the launcher, you can edit the memory settings like it says, but some people still get the issue. I have fixed it for the most part, but some people can't. Maybe the devs will fix this or optimize it.Other than these, that's all I got for the cons. Great right? lolNow, this section is WHY it is NOT a clone of Space Engineers.1. It is blocks, not voxels.2. It has planets, stars (Stars that you can actually go to and burn up and die, not just the background sun), sectors, systems, and galaxies.3. It ALREADY has NPCs, I know SE will have them, but this game already does.4. It has customizable weapons and complex combination systems.5. It has more than just 1 type of metal block. Just saying lol.6. Build mode/advanced build mode.7. More content with factions (SO FAR).*Don't get me wrong, I still love and play Space Engineers, but I wanted to clear this up for people who think this is a clone because it most certainly is not**ONE MORE THING BEFORE WE WRAP THIS UP* It is still early access (For those who don't know what that means), it is still being developed, it will change, get worse, get fixed, get better, and maybe even become something different.*TL;DR*Now, for the people who didn't feel like reading all of that, here is a basic summary:It is an incredibly fun game with many unique features, and very few bugs that I have noticed. Not many cons at all, and I suggest this to any person. STILL early access so things will change, get worse, get fixed, get better and maybe even become something different. NOT a clone of Space Engineers. (I covered that in the above section)*FOR THOSE WHO READ THE WHOLE THING* Thanks for taking the time to read and I hope you found this helpful. :)

Early Access Review
								After creating "La Scrubs" faction with a friend, we built a ship with a hyper-drive to fly to a randomly generated quadrant of the galaxy, found and took over a space station then took apart our old ship, attatched the hyper-drive to the space station, and used the newly adapted space-ship-station to fly into a partially loaded planet. The planet, which had not loaded in properly, now had a gigantic space station sticking out of it! Unfortunately the planet's core is a stationary object, so we couldn't use the hyper-drive to fly the space-ship-station-planet into a moon. :(

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Once upon a time...no, wait, never mind.  I'm still bulding the U.S.S Defiant.StarMade is a block-buildy game In Space!  The best way to explain it to people is, to start by imagining MineCraft.  Now, take your awesome castle, and put thrusters and guns on it.  That's StarMade...only, it's not quite as engaging, even about seven months after my original review.  Some changes have happened, including a price hike to $14.99.  Thus, I'm taking the extra hours I've played in the intervening months into account, and doing a re-review.  Has it improved?  Well...you will see.What WorksFirst, the visuals have improved greatly from my prior review, and the game overall looks pretty nice.  You can build some neat ships and stations.  The Pentas/Tetras/Corners allow for somewhat blocky re-builds of your favorite Sci-Fi ships, or your own custom creations.  Some recent texture updates from the developers have made good ships look even better!Performance is also improved to the point where the game is at least playable on medium-grade machines.  This was a critical problem for me in my previous review, but the developers deserve credit for working to make the game behave more efficiently.  Good job there!The UI has improved a lot in seven months too.  There are some issues with resizing individual windows, but the game is easily understandable via the UI, and gives you most of the tools you need to build ships, which is the game's primary mechanic.  The secondary mechanic, shooting stuff with your ship, is also well-accounted for, with shield, structural HP, and armor HP being presented well.  There are some placeholders about, as this game is still in development, but progress is being made.  I'm sure seven months in the future, the UI will be a lot better than it already is, and I look forward to that.What Doesn't WorkBefore I get to anything heavy, I have to talk about the crafting system.  The crafting system is OK in a survival setting, and some much-needed tuning has happened...but ultimately, to make a decent ship, you need a lot of blocks, because in this game, bigger ship = better.  There's additional problems with that that we will get to, but the crafting system as it stands actually hampers the process of doing the main thing that you should be doing in a game about building starships: actually building starships.  To solve this, the crafting UI and system needs a pretty massive interface revamp, and some thought should be taken to all the 'wasted' blocks about, things like plantlife that could be leveraged to make more interesting builds.  It's as if the developers started off by copying MineCraft, then at some point decided, "oh yeah, the point of this game is to make ships!"Next, there's a problem with how the shipbuilding mechanics in this game are balanced, specifically: any ship you make is a fighter.  You don't need crews to tend to large ships.  You just need your ship to be bigger than an enemy's, because a bigger ship fits more systems in it, and systems are what cause you to win fights, eat asteroids or planets, or whatever.  The recent Cargo system that was released yesterday will help prevent planet-eating miners from being quite as big of a problem as they were prior to this (good luck fitting a planet in your cargo holds), but those of you wondering whether or not to buy into this game should know that, especially in multiplayer, the shipbuilding mechanic is unfairly weighted towards building big ships; smaller ships are thus forced out of niches that are realistic, such as bombers/interceptors.As big of problems as those points are, there was one critical problem in my prior review, that there's nothing really to do, no reason to actually build a ship.  This one, big, critical, overarching problem persists to this day, and it makes the entire game, all the well-crafted bits, completely pointless.  There are some feeble attempts to remedy this - specifically a "race gate" minigame setup was added to the game in a more recent release.The reason I say, "there is nothing to do in StarMade", is tied more specifically to two things.In Single-Player, there's really nothing to explore.  StarMade randomly generates universes, but other than finding slightly different ores on planets, you may as well not bother.  There are randomly generated space stations too, but do they reward anything?  Not really, unless you salvage the station.  In StarMade, you'll soon discover one thing: due to how the Crafting system works (above), it's generally better to avoid conflict altogether, or your lovingly-crafted spaceship will cease to be, and you will have to grind out a new ship.In Multi-Player, it gets worse.  The Faction system in StarMade is...well, a faction system.  Ideally, players pool their resources to create fleets, stations, and stuff, thus providing a natural objective for PvP.  Sounds great, right?  Unfortunately, due to not designing the Faction system to account for humanity's darker impulses, the only way to secure anything you own, is to create a one-man faction, and set a planet or space station as the home base...rendering the systems inoperable by non-guildmembers, and storage secure.  In this way, your stuff is safe from griefing, and as far as I can tell, it's the way the game is designed to be played.  That's well and good...except that's not really the point of a Faction, now is it?.The way I suggest for the developers to fix StarMade's pointlessness is two-fold.  First, there needs to be a meaningful progression that doesn't come out of your workbenches.  You should have to explore, and give exploration some meaning besides "where are the ores?"  If you want to create a civilian ship, ask yourself: why create a civilian ship?  Trade, mining, and ferrying come to mind.  Those are some great candidates for randomized quests that can be rewarded with blocks, money, or useful ship blueprints.  For that matter - make the premade ships not suck so much!  Existing ships can serve a great purpose - teaching new players the nuances of StarMade's shipbuilding mechanics.  In this way, players build better, interesting ships, which forges a stronger community and makes PvP more reasonable as an implicit objective.Next, you have to fix factions.  Single-player factions destroy the fun of multiplayer in this game.  My suggestion is for players to have 'personal home' blocks that can be used to secure a personal space on a station or planet against anyone who's not them; all chests/cargo areas in that are similarly preserved.  Similarly, creating a faction should require a party of at least two people.  The home-base constraint can still apply, and should.   The game needs better in-faction control to help Factions defend against spies and ne'erdowells.  As long as players make single-person factions, your multiplayer is broken.  You're just putting single-player on a multi-player server.The TL;DRI have a love-hate relationship with this game.  On the one hand, I really do like building starships.  On the other, this game is less of a "game" in the "you can win or lose" sense, and more of a starship building simulator.  The price of the game was increased to $14.99 from $9.99...I see nothing that justifies this price hike.  As a result, I emphatically do not recommend purchasing StarMade.This game will be fun, possibly for weeks, until you begin to see the legion of flaws and the fact that this game is a simulator.  $14.99 is how much completed indie games cost on Steam; this game is neither completed, nor sufficiently fun enough to bear that price tag.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I highly recommend this game to any and everybody that likes Sci-Fi Space themed action games and also has a knack for Minecraft. You'll find that you can literally do ANYTHING of your choosing in this game, and honestly of all the alpha games I have ever played, this feels almost like something beyond a complete game, with the exception of a few bugs. A warning to someone that just starts this game: You'll NEED to look up tutorials, and you'll NEED to use the wiki. (I recommend Starmadepedia). I'll summarize my expierience thus far.Started Playing GameDid TutorialBuilt a Crappy ShipCombines a post I saw on steam + Some new found knowledge and made a Mining ShipSpent upwards of 2 hours mining a small area of asteroidsSold the minerals to the local shopBought a faction module to find a place to settle and claimBought a Space StationClaimed a System after building a small stationMade a goal to be able to mine Asteroids in secondsDid more MiningMore MiningUpgraded Ship to the point it could easily eat an asteroid in a minute or lessRead a Post that said you could blow up planetsMade the ambitous goal to mine away entire planets and then blow them up (Or vice versa)More MiningSetup factories that were super efficient (You can increase factory outputs with Factory Enchancers)Built a whole bunch of parts to add on to my systemLearned about Cannon Computers to Salvage ComputersUpgraded my systemCould now mine entire planets, but not destroy themLearned about Nuke MissilesMade a system with a Pulse Module Slaved to a Missile Module for Nukes compiling a 2.3k block arrayLearned that my nuke used way to much powerDid a bunch of swearingTripled my power storage and reactor setup to accomadate my nuke setupMore swearing because it couldn't accomadate the setupDoubled the reactor and power setup again, along with adding Lasers and CannonsFinally was able to launch nukes Blew up a worldLagged out the ServerGot back on ServerStarted raiding a nearby Pirate StationSlowly built up ship till it could take out Pirate StationStarted helping newbies with newbie issuesBlew up another world and mined all its contents to impress said newbiesThis was about 2 days worth a play time total,  and I did not regret a single second of it :)

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								THREE EDITS HAVE BEEN MADE SINCE THE INITIAL WRITING OF THIS REVIEW, THEY ARE DOWN THE BOTTOM FOR YOUR CONVENIANCEThe simple observation that a lot of white knights/fanboys are roaming this games reviews and mass disliking any review that speaks bad of this game speaks volumes about the community of this game. As for the game itself:Pros: Easily the best building system in any voxel based game I have seen recentlyHaving now played Avorion I can no longer stand by this statement, the building system in Avorion is essentialy a better version of StarMade's building systemMore voxel shapes for you to chose from and the ability to change the dimensions of said shapes (in StarMade every shape is the same size and the only way to make a "bigger wedge" is to place multiple wedges) combined with the ability to disable the snap grid and completely freebuild is something that StarMade's building system cannot compare too.The possibilities presented by StarMades logic system are endlessCons:PvP is a mess, extreme weapon and combat system inbalance combined with the idea that bigger ships will always win make for unfun experience. The engine created by Schine cannot handle combat on any scale unless the server is running on top of the line hardware that most server owners do not have the budget to maintain, especialy considering there are not enough players left in the game to run a server off donations.PvE is practicaly nonexistant, the NPC update did take a step in the right direction but PvE is pretty much going to pirate stations and AFK farming them with logic activated missile+missile weaponsMining and industry is a massive bordem simulator and nobody is interested in buying from other players and prefer to make everything for themselves, playing as a merchant or an industry corperation/faction is simply not practical or fun unless you are on an enforced roleplay server. Worth noting that any servers that encourage/enforce roleplay are empty 99% of the timeThe developers and the a large amount of the players would rather reject and insult people who are critical of the game then take on these criticisms or make valid arguments as to why they are wrong.The games popularity and people actually playing the game are on a downward trend-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------It should be noted that this review is based on 4 years of playing this game, having 500 hours in the steam client and thousands more in the standalone launcher, I have participated in almost every form of gameplay this game has to offer in addition to seeing many faces of this community come and go for reasons similar to my own, namely Mushroom Fleet and ToasterBorstEDIT: I should have probably mentioned that while this game is in alpha development stage (which is a common excuse used by the roaming white knights to justify the games problems) this game has been in this alpha stage for 6 years as of the time of this review, in my opinion that is ridiculousEDIT 2: A message to SchellBier, mappa. Look its cool that you want to harass me over steam via the profile commenting section, I really don't care and I am not going to heed to your demmands for me to delete my review because its "non-construtive and not helping the game grow" I have and I will continue to delete those comments, please keep them coming however, I would love to get a good quality screenshot before I delete them since you want to try and claim that you never harrassed me.EDIT 3: Seeing as some whiteknights are trying to say that I am "campaigning against the game" and I am "known throughout the community as a troll" I just wanted to quash those statements and state that if you had actualy read my review you would easily see that at the very top of the review I actualy wrote positive aspects about the game, even saying that one aspect of this game is the best in any game I have seen. All in all, saying that I am "campainging against the game" is extremely hypocritical, and by your own logic you are campainging against any and all negative criticism, going as far as attempting to misuse steams report function to try and get mine, ToasterBorst's and several other negative reviews censored/deleted.EDIT 4: One of the StarMade whitenights (mappa) has threatended civil action against me because I published proof of harrassment by mappa over of my review. The fact that its gotten to the point where they are willing to resort to using the legal system because of negative steam reviews against games that they whiteknight is just a futher testamony to the type of community this game has (especialy the whiteknights)

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								VERY GREAT GAME**Before anyone says anything about "You only have 19 hours and you're saying you played 7 days," I came on for a least a hour or two every each of these days, however when the war broke out; it lasted 4-6 hours.****EDIT 2**In regards to my prestine base, I actually just crashed my Ex-Starship, "Interstellar X," into my planet causing everything to go kaboom. Server crashed, end of story. **EDIT 1**Summary 2: In my opinion guys, this is by far the most thrilling, most intriguing game you will EVER play on Steam. ***** Space Engineers, give StarMade a try! I gaurantee you, it's worth every penny. Day 30: The Void has now become the most largest fleet in the entire server (server is remaining hidden, if you find us, hehehe :P). The Void now controls over 90 Sectors in several galaxies and is the heart of the SOS Network. With over 78 fleet members, we are controlling to largest vessal known as the "Void Battlecruiser Mk. XII." With this strong vessal at hand, it holds a crew of 50 and cargo capacity of over 1 million blocks (Standard NDAs apply :3). Being the fleet's first commanding officer, I resign to other duties in another galaxy. Where I live a happy life in my prestine starbase (which saddly blew up because of a reactor meltdown :( )Day 1: Was a complete noob, downloaded several ships from the forums, just to see what it was like.Day 2: Joined a server, made new friends, and created a dream. Day 3: Mining starts, we set out to get several thousands of minerals.Day 4: Space Station bought, now heavy armor production begins; shield systems online, advanced anti-ship weaponry online.Day 5: Production of S.O.S. BattleShip, The Void, begins. More additions to Space Station.Day 6: War comes alive; multiple squads of highly suited pirates are approaching, we respond by sending 2 squadrons (of 4 ships each) to attack the hostile parties. While our fleet is attacking the pirates, I am aboard the Fleet Space Station, initiating Emergency Protocol Omega when I see Alpha Squad has been blown to bits. 4 more Squads of pirates come up on radar, the Station is now in red alert, warp gates are firing up for our last ditch effort. Shields are down to 75% and dropping fast, Bravo Squad is fleeing from the Station. Shields are now down to 69%, warp gates are at 85% charge, I quickly launch our Escape Pod Protocol, everybody aboard the Station is now aboard the only highly advanced pod we had. The warp gates are now ready to teleport, Escape Pod 1 is entering transit, all our advanced anti-ship weaponry are covering their taxi towards the gate. My fleet are shouting at me to come aboard quick, when I realize I am the only one keeping them from death. I am the last stand against the threat, Escape Pod 1 is now entering the warp gate, any time now they will be safe, sectors away from the threat. Shields are now at 27%, we just lost power as soon as Escape Pod 1 enters the warp gate. With power at criticly low levels, I initiate the emergency shielding systems, when ... another fleet arrives!? This can't be, our neighboring fleet has come to the rescue! With over 8 squadrons of advanced fighters, they broke out a very thrilling war. With Anti-Ship guns firing at the pirates and our neighboring fleet to the rescue, power is coming back online on the Station. The Void Space Station is now fully operational, with her crew at Echo Base. The pirates are fleeing from the battlefield, we've defeated them! Thanks to the help if our neighbors, our Space Station is forever safe. Day 7: We have completed the S.O.S. BattleShip TheVoid. Space Station Alpha has been upgraded extensively. Anti-Ship weaponry has been refitted with even more advanced weaponry. Summary: Oh, my, god.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Don't be fooled by the number of hours played on Steam. I've been a longtime supporter of StarMade, and have played hundreds of hours before the Steam release.StarMade is a sci-fi voxel based sandbox game.If I had to pick a game that it feels similar to, I would say Minecraft. There is a comparable level of addictivness, as well as a somewhat greater level for truly amazing creations.Simply put, StarMade is really, really good. In it's current state, the schine team are working hard on bugfixes, rebalancing, and adding awesome new content. There will be builds that change the balance of ships, so you will need to redo some ship systems entirely.---------------+ building is simple and easy to master+ there is crafting, so you can start with nothing on the surface of a planet and work your way up+ in-depth faction system+ community makes some fantastic things+ logic system has unlimited potential (like redstone but better)+ visually stunning+ game is made for multiplayer, and handles it just as well as singleplayer+ constant optimization and bugfixes from devs---------------- Not a finished product- Still in development, there will be bugs, there will be changes you won't like immediately. You just need to deal with it and be patient.---------------FEATURES:> Practically infinite universe> Ship building, station building> Solar systems> Suns, Planets, Asteroids> Black holes and wormholes> Warp Gates and Jump Drives> Logic system> Factions > others I can't think of right nowPLANNED/UPCOMING FEATURES:> Creatures> Quests> Better Ai

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been playing this game for awhile before it hit steam so my hours might be a bit skewed.  I'm gonna list some features I like below, and as the game grows I will add onto this list, and other things.-Liked Features ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------   -People don't move or skit around when on ships. This is a big one, and a lot of space building games have players glitching or even getting stuck in walls becuase they don't treat the ship as a anchor.    -Much like an open world game. If you see it you can probably go to it. This game blows my mind on how expansive it is. You see that red dot in the distance? Thats a star, you can go there. That yellow dot? Another star. Seriously this game is crazy with this stuff and it blows my mind.   -Populated servers. If you haven't played on a server yet do it. Great expierence.  -Movable Asteroids. Its just fun to push them around, or even use them for cover.  -Block Variety. This is another big one for me becuase its real nice to have a large list of blocks just to build nice looking ships with.   -Advanced & Basic building. You can go very advanced with building in this game to get the most efficiency out of ships, or you can go basic, and get a alright ship.   -Logic Systems. Probably one of the best things a building game can include, absolutely amazing!  -Planets. You can even orbit them, or mine them out! Seriously planets are amazing they even have there own axis of rotation.   -Wormholes. You can travel throughout the galaxy on wormholes.  -Pirates. While they variety is lacking in the base vanilla game, you can add in your own Custom Pirates into the game.  -PVP. Great expierence this one its fun watching two giant frigates battle it outside a planet.   -Weapon Combinations. Probably one of my favourite features. Being able to combine a Rocket with a Cannon to make a shotgun is just the best. -Breaching. It was done alright fun as all hell though.   -Shipyards. Absolutely amazing. Although I don't use it much its really fun to see a friend dock his        ship into our base.  - Great Tutorial. Gotta say helped me out a bunch! ~Developers + Support Team~ --------------------------------------------------------------------   - While I am not a developer my self I will say that they probably have one of the best support teams and dev's I have seen in early acess. I reported a bug about a wormhole spawning in my spawn when I first got the game and within a day it was on the bug tracker and my issue fixed! The developers also keep frequent updates, and are amazingly active on the forums.    - The demo is the full game. This is amazing for early access you are giving players a chance to play the game, and see if they want to support you! Great move on the creators.    - If you are gonna do early acess this is how you do it right!~Servers~ -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------   - My expierence with servers have been fun. If you are gonna play starmade you absolutely gotta do it in a server. The game normally feels empty in singleplayer but in multiplayer servers usually add there own custom pirates, and tons of players populate the game! Seriously give this a shot.~Community~    - Probably one of the friendliest communities I have ever met! Seriously they are a major help and I suggest you visit the forums here. " http://starmadedock.net/forums/ "~Some bad things~ -------------------------------------------------------------------------A review isn't a review without some bad things. The game is still early acess so I won't really put bug complaints here.(This list may grow)- Windows block out some things. Not sure if this is a bug or intended, but you cannot see the sun, planets cores, and missiles through certain pieces of glass. If this was intended maybe instead of blocking out all particles like that you can just dim them.*~~~~~~* ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is absolutly  epic,  the best way for me to review this for you is to guide you through my first few real life days in the game.  Day 1:  I started by myself built a ship core added thrusters, cannons and and mining beams mined asteroids for a few hours and with those resources built/bought shields for my ship. with my shields up and cannons ready I go to the nearest pirate station... After spending about 5 minutes with red beams flashing everywhere around my ship and me firing to no effect on the station I decide to close the range... cause i thought my cannons where out of range... I must say the shield hit effects were epic and they were the last things i saw before my ship imploded. that ended my first day. Day 2:  I play with my friend with a few of his mates and we build a small planetary hideout kitted out with basic factory and power generation capabilities along with a bit of a decorative sense. we decide to build a space station and begin work on ceaser station.  Day 3:  After an all nighter building our station it is finally completed We look upon our basic station with pride it had an internal medium hanger bay and a small exterior bay. little did we know that while we were building our lttle station the others had been amassing a fleet. Blissfully unaware we continue expanding our station. making a cool interior command room, hanger observation room, a working red alert system with logic blocks and a nice room to watch the planet we were orbiting from. Day 4:  My friend and I are discussing on skype what our plans are for the station today as we connect to the server. We decide to build another (larger) hanger bay and a med bay. While im working on setting up the docking zones for the large hanger my friend decides to go out in our mining ship to replenish our rapdily depleting supply of money and materials. While he is out I notice 4 new contacts appear on my screen all of a sudden, blissfully unaware I check my navigation bar to see what the new contacts are. Bunny Buster, Major Pain, Meals on Thrusters and 1701. I wondered if they wanted to trade with us (we had just set up our shop) so I asked them if they would like to dock... the response i got was not the one i hoped for... One ship fired what must of been over a hundred missiles all of which quickly turned to face the station and our fighter craft and begun to speed towards us. Realising we were under attack I screamed for reinforcements from my friend and ran for the fighter hoping to get into it and fly off to allow its shield to recharge. The first volley of missiles totaly obliterated that hope, I watched as the core (all that survived of my fighter) spun past overheating. And decided to do the last thing that I could, I ran for the control center deep in the center of our station hoping that the attackers would get bored before they shot through all the intervening rooms and armour blocks. Upon reaching the control room I played my last card... I activated the Red alert system we had spent half an hour setting up. Immediatly all the lights in our station turned off... and .5 seconds later red ones turned on to replace them. That done I activated the build block so I could watch them destory my work. The ship that fired all the missiles was now steaidly pouring barrages of missiles into the station which while not having much dammage lowered our shields slowly. A second ship oppened up with Ion beams (as i latter found out) which almost instantly stripped the remaining shields from our station. The remaining two ships then closed and each fired a single missile one they had coloured green the other red. I thought that my station could easily withstand two missiles I mean it had surrived hundreds so far... how wrong I was each missile detonated with all the fury of a nuclear weapon punching giant holes in our beutiful home (turns out they had mergered pulse and missile blocks to make these missiles). I watched on as they fired the seconds volley and counted the seconds till  my command centre exploded around me. and so ended my 4th day. Day 5:  I joined up with the  ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s  AWESOME GUYS who destroyed my station so i could learn their ways... and boy did I learn lots ;-)This Game lets you do SO MUCH, every weapon can be merged with other weapons to create different effects e.g cannon to cannon to create a rapid fire cannon (good for missile defence if mounted on a turret) Pulse to missile makes the lock on nukes. Missile to Missile make swarm missiles which independantly lock on to hostile targets. There are jump drives, cloaking devices (which I recently figured out how to use) Scanners, Radar jammers And more. This game is great and getting better10/10 strongly suggest you buy it! If you do and your interested in multiplayer please tell me.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								BUY THIS GAME.I'm writing this review at the end of 2014, and I must say that StarMade turned out to be a bit of a dark horse contender for my personal GOTY (and that's going up against amazing games like Shadow of Mordor, DA: I, and Endless Legend). I've had more fun with it than I ever had with Minecraft, despite the obvious similarities between the two games. I find myself thinking about StarMade when I'm at work, plotting out new ship designs and planning raids on other factions. I cannot recommend this game highly enough.So what's the appeal? Why is StarMade so great?For me, the answer is that it fulfills the promises of games like Space Engineers, Eve, STO, and even legendary franchises like the X series. It is one of the first sci-fi games I've ever played that strikes a perfect balance between space combat, ground combat, ship design, strategy, and a vibrant in-game economy. The game is still early-access, and this is somewhat obvious at times (particularly on planets, which currently do not spawn pregenerated structures or mobs), but there's just so damned much to DO - particularly if you're playing online - that you'll rarely care.One of the most appealing aspects of the game is ship and station design. You'll start off floating in the void of space, somewhere near the center of a proc-gen galaxy. You have 25, 000 credits and some basic building components, which can be used to make a large fighter, or, more likely, a small, all-purpose vessel. Whatever you decide, every single aspect of the design is up to you. Want a donut-shaped ship? Do it! Want to fly Moya, the Galactica, or the USS Enterprise? It'll be expensive, but it's totally doable. Want turbolifts between decks, drone racks, or a tractor beam? Build the right components and you can install them anywhere you want on your ship. Be careful though, because every block you place serves an important purpose - and every block can be destroyed. This means you can lose gravity partway through a fight, potentially jettisoning your friends into the void of space. Or perhaps the logic that controls your turbolifts will go down, trapping you on the command deck until repairs can be made. StarMade is, IMO, the most complex and well-executed science-fiction simulator available, with its infinite possibilities offering countless moments of drama, terror, and triumph.I could keep raving about how great this game is, but, well, I kinda want to play it instead. I HIGHLY recommend that anyone who's a fan of sci-fi or sandbox games give the game a whirl. Trust me, the $10 or so that they're asking for is an absolute steal.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Don't let my paltry game play time fool you, I've played at least a hundred hours of this game prior to it coming to steam. It was great. Sure, it is technically in the development phase even now, but if you are curious of whether to purchase this game or not, I would have to say it is likely worth the buy considering the following:1. Final version will likely be much more expensive, so buy it now to support it's development and get it cheap!2. Despite the level of development, there is so much to do. Seriously, people are still posting versions of famous starships rebuilt for starmade while others create their own original ships.3. The community is fantastic! If you have the ability to, you should try setting up a server for you and your friends.Lastly, many of the complaints I have heard of this game are technical in nature and have been already fixed as of this review. There is only one complaint I have worth mentioning and that is the fact that the system requirements are probably a little higher than listed here. I have a good setup beyond what is required here, but I have to turn down the settings to play this game without issue. I do not believe this game to be as poorly optimised as minecraft, but it definitely can slow down or screw up if you do not alter the settings. Even so, this flaw can be ignored as this game is already becoming a nearly perfect addition to the indie game market.Definitely a must own for any creative mind.LET ME ADD MORE TO THIS REVIEW! as of 11/24/2016:I cheated on Starmade with Space Engineers for a while. I was foolish. Sure, Space Engineers may be prettier, but it is a shallow and hollow husk of what Starmade is. I began hanging out again with my main lady, Starmade recently. She didn't hold my terrible mistakes against me, and we have had plenty of fun since. Miss Starmade even had even been working out while I was gone, she's more attractive than ever, and even runs at a good bit faster of a pace than before. Starmade even has a few new tricks up her sleeve she learned while I was gone. Better yet, she's still learning and buffing up, so I know things between us will only get better.In the end, let me say that I respect Starmade for what she is, an expressive and fun individual with a quirky personality and plenty of love to share.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Arms Race in SpaceIt’s been about two hours of furious clicking, and I still haven’t finished this battlecruiser. I am so focused on getting this done so that I can as soon as possible take it into outer space and blow the crap out of my rivalling faction’s outpost that lies 9 solar systems away. I must prove like many other factions in StarMade, that the “ACE Pirates” is a faction that are to be taken seriously and I am sure that when this battlecruiser is done, they will never even consider launching a missile at even the weakest of our mining ships.StarMade is all about building spaceships and continuously upgrading them as time flies by while having such a blast. Whenever one thought that one’s interstellar battlecruiser was too big, an hour or two later they will not think so anymore. StarMade creates this need, this addiction to keep on destroying, keep on mining and to keep on building that spaceship of yours that you will brag about to all the people on the server – until someone with some space dreadnought that is twice your size shoves a missile down your throat. When such things happen, StarMade emotionally attached you to that ship, and it emotionally attached you to making that ship beat someone else’s. StarMade makes you think of your spaceship as your children, you want the best out of them and you keep on encouraging them – or even force them to be better that others. That’s what happens when you get this thought; “how shall I build this weapon system to one-shot that guy?”.At first StarMade would seem very similar to Minecraft – which it is in both its aesthetics and fundamental gameplay. They are both games based on blocks and building. But apart from that it has what Minecraft lacked and made me stuck to the game ever since, namely to be able to build space ships. Not only are the textures so much sharper, and the building materials come in different shapes apart from cubes, but the scale of StarMade is just outstanding. Robin Promesberger spent a decade to code the engine for it and runs so well on even low end pcs. With this you soar the universe, explore millions of different planets, solar systems and galaxies. There is not one world, but hundreds to explore – all in one game!If you thought space was lonely and think that it’ll be like that in StarMade, I’m sorry but you thought wrong. StarMade’s multiplayer is a fantastic experience of interacting, trading, obliterating and befriending your fellow astronauts in this vast universe of space. Not only is it fun to mine and survive in space alongside them, but joining a faction by teaming up and creating a coalition can be just as exciting. A fully established faction will sometimes be forced to operate in such a way that is almost as complex as modern day politics! For example, a leader that divides certain members to either build, produce blocks, fight or mine. Mine where? When? How? With what? These are all fundamental questions that must be solved within the faction, forcing the players themselves to figure out what’s best for them and for the faction so that they can stand out as a better faction. This is StarMade’s multiplayer experience, which is both unique and enjoyable for the casual to hardcore gamer.  I mentioned continuously upgrading your spaceship and how this hooks you onto the game. To be able to continuously upgrade your ship by adding more modules, more shields, more guns, you have more or less no limits opposed to other scifi shooting games. Your ship depends all on how well you can plan, how well you choose to get resources, and of course how well you design your ship with all these resources you get. Much like the modpacks for Minecraft such as tekkit and feedthebeast, you can build huge factory complexes. In StarMade these are the essential and fundamental parts for wrecking space scrubs in the universe. It takes a long time to get a hang of it, and there is quite a steep learning curve, but you’ll eventually understand the game, and when you do you can do anything you ever wished to do in in space. The part of StarMade that I find most satisfying is when you explode someone’s ship with a missile whilst piloting the spacecraft made of all those resources which you collected and strived hard to turn into modules in your factory complex. It is very amusing to watch the guy’s dead ship drift away for you to take. Like more or less everything in this universe, there has to always be the downsides. StarMade unfortunately lacks many sounds for certain parts of the game and gives a less immersive feel. Currently the game has a very limited AI simulation, which means that playing the single player mode will feel very lonely. However this can be quickly solved by hopping on to the first multiplayer server in the conveniently placed server list that exists in the launcher. StarMade also lacks a proper third person view perspective, something I and probably many other people think is a natural view point in games. But for being in alpha, that is quite alright, and the gameplay itself is outstanding and addictive to say the least. StarMade is about building stuff, and sometime later blow stuff up with that stuff. The intense multiplayer creates the competitiveness to progress with designing your ships, and forces this competitiveness to go on. And in the process, forces you to blow up one another in this blocky arms race in space. The Good+ Infinite universe, + Smooth immersive multiplayer, + Well established ship building system+ Rewarding progressionThe Bad- Lack of AI simulation- No third person view- Few sounds.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played this game many hours, and I mean, I played it a lot. I'm more than a year active on some servers now, and I had a lot of fun.But like every song, the fun comes slowly to an end, and it starts to bore me. When I played this game for the first time, it was the incredible possibilities that kept me hooked. Spaceships, small and big, stations... and thanks to the rail function and logic, I was busy for a while..I met many players, and build a lot. And we showed off with what we had. But there is an interesting problem. Starmade isn't an RTS where you can spawn ships like cheap cannon fodder for war. You put almost your soul in these ships, which makes you more reserved to battle against friend or foe. Especially big ships... which takes a lot of time and resources to build them... It isn't far-fetched to see some  players raged-quit after losing their capital ship....The planets are... not really interesting. Sometimes you find even an 'artefact'  on these planets and  they are very rare. But not good enough to explore the galaxy. After a while you will see them nothing more than as something to mine, and a message that you killed a lot of people (which is in my opinion still a dead planet if there's nothing that moves on it than only yourself) if you blow them up, shrugs you off  like something not important....They're too small to be important and interesting, and still too big, because they can often lag your computer...The only interesting thing in the galaxy are the players and even that starts to bore you, because the action is rare between them. You have some guys that like to grieve you, but that looks almost like the pinnacle of the game, really....Battle between ships is a problem too. Forget the small ships. They are just fodder. A battle is almost based on 1:1  system. The ship with the most (shield and shield regen) blocks (almost) wins. When you fight with two Battleships against one Titan, you can count on it that one battleship will be heavy damaged, probably will be destroyed...You can simply forget the epic battle with many small ships (5000-15000 blocks) against a Capital ship of almost 4 million blocks with an heavy shield. Even if you came with 80 (that will probably lags the server),  you will lose them, just because they have not enough fire-power and  a weak shield.  (the 10 second punishment time after losing your shield is just deadly for small ships)But that is just about ships and battle.What I really miss in this game is the reward system.  Why would I explore the galaxy if there are no hidden treasure or secrets? Why would I battle if there are no special rewards?It would be a dream, If I found a blueprint of a special block on a planet  that would give me an upperhand in battles, like a stronger shield block or power block and weapon. Or special ores for these blocks. Just think about that.They are working on AI factions now.... They just put new players in the field, but without an interesting reward system, they will bore you fast enough....I don't think the programmers will read this review, but you get the idea.Still, is this game worth it? I say yes, it's a great game for your creative dreams. But I can only hope that they don't forget an really good reward system then a cloud of blocks from pirates..., otherwise it will only be a building game....

number of helpful: 72 of 78 people (92%) found this review helpful15 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I started off loving Starmade...then we broke up. Now I spend time thinking about maybe giving it a another shot. I got into the game just after the big graphical re-boot having played Minecraft for years and checking out every voxel based, procedurally generated game I could find. I trolled Greenlight and found many wanna be contenders but Starmade impressed me with it's vision of what it wants to be. Like any relationship we fall in love with what could be, an ideal, sometimes a projection we place onto the other. I am love with what Starmade is trying to be, but has not yet become.   I lost interest for awhile when the docking update changed how turrets and ships dock. I was having a blast using the quirky old system to make a wide range of ships. The new system looks great and will solve many foibles and allow for a great variety of new designs. Just like with the Minecraft updates I got to enjoy a new game play each time Notch added something. Starmade is developing much the same way but because of it's own ambition each major update is quite disruptive. I have seen other early access wallow aimlessly, become abandoned or run off the rails in development. Starmade is doing none of these things. The danger, as I see it, is that Starmade may have trouble fulfilling it's grand ambitions.   Yes this game has a learning curve and I had fun riding that curve. This is the gold-standard for a complex game. If the learning is fun; success, if it is tedious; go play a game more suited to your short attention-span. A simple game is easy to learn and may become boring. A game with depth and possibilities is going take time to master but will remain engaging.   In it's current state (shipyards just released) Starmade is a very solid, playable early access game. There is a smattering of enemies to keep you improving your ship designs. There is no story arc yet but the ship-building is very polished. The Devs have built a proper foundation for an amazing game. It remains to be seen if they can build an engaging experience onto their ground-breaking mechanics while maintaining balance.   Look elsewhere for the hate, I'm going to tell you what I love.>Design matters. Where you put modules and how you protect your ship will really make a difference. Lots of room for tactics, countermeasures and cool systems. My first death in the game was a suicide. I designed anti-personnel pulsers in the airlock. Two passes and you are still ok, the third pass: you're dead. (You can come in, look around and leave safely or... linger and die.) I died testing the system and laughed my♥♥♥♥♥off.>If you can dream it up you can build it. The first major ship I built was a salvage craft. I designed it to rescue shipwrecks. It was big and turned like a pig but fast and survivable. (I used it for daring rescue of a huge ship that got cored by pirates. It was an epic mission that left massive chucks missing from the old Flat-top but both vessels made it home intact. WooHoo)   One of my favorites is the Tholian Enervater: a spider-themed hunter-killer. By design this craft can pursue a small fighter, slow it down using (web) multiple tractor beams (locking it in the crosshairs), rob it of power using (venom) an electro-mcGuffin ray and finally kill it. The theme of the spider worked both visually and tactically. Very Cool, good job Devs.   I decided to make a Whale-ship that could swallow a pirate-craft whole and then eat it. It worked just as I had hoped. (Unfortunately collisions are unavoidable)   I have stealth designs, a 'Tuttle-craft' for repairs, a surveyer/scout, a carrier/salvager, a mining ship with a huge beam.  = ]  Racing has just been introduced so now 'Tuning' will be a part of designing an efficient racer.> Hey, it's fun to fly too. Never mind the awesome build mode with simple and powerful symmetry & mirroring to reduce keystrokes... this is a very good space cockpit interface. Starmade features a huge number of elements introduced by previous space games but incorporates them well, often getting better results than its predecessors. It may not have the graphical grandeur of Klingon Academy but the systems controls are simple and easy to use in combat. After narrowly escaping from battle and badly damaged, I was able to reconfigure my systems and piece two non-functional weapons into one cobbled together mess of a gun (without going into build-mode). As I limped home I felt like Scotty, under an instrument panel with sparks flying, griping to the ham fisted captain who got us into this mess in the first place (oh, wait...that's me).    Dog fighting is still a bit slow and not very dynamic with the current AI. I hope for more variation in their tactics besides "Send more guys".  Multiplayer servers often have custom pirates so there is lots of room for variety.>Potential. There's that dirty word again. With human crews for opponents in a more populated (by NPCs) world this game could be epic on a level beyond the average tired space-shooter game. It already has nailed the galactic map, shop-economy, building, flight control, and optimization. Read the developer's blog (Bench) to get a look at what is to come. The game updates every couple of weeks with new features, bug fixes and optimizations.>Powerful logic-driven systems. Think wireless redstone only more stable. Weapons with aux effects, electronic countermeasures and transporters. Shipyards to generate virtual designs and a BluePrint for your builds to save, share, upload, download & modify, all seamlessly.>Friendliest PvP I have ever seen in a game.>This game is better and more polished in it's Alpha state than many 'finished' releases I have bought. >Going into 2016 there has been a cargo and thruster update offering realistic, mass based acceleration and more thruster dynamics with user customizable settings. Fleets are set to add another dimension to the Meta-game. Slabs are expanding build-potential.   For the earth bound crowd who complain that game is broken: try to find it in your imagination that this game is still in the chrysalis phase. The grub's body is utterly dissolved in the cocoon before it can be reborn into a butterfly.    Early access is just that... if you don't get that stop bothering the developers and go play something with Zombies.    For the Developers: Schine on.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								I may have one of the most hours played on Starmade... So I feel I can create a decent review...Starmade, is a must have game. There, there's my review.As of Aug. 11 2015 Have you ever eaten a pretty bad meal out for about 12 bucks? Afterwards you regret going there in ther first place because all you're doing now is sitting on the toilet and hating yourself? Well starmade isn't like that at all. It costs less than $12.00 currently, at $9.99. It also will make you not hate yourself! :D (Well, unless you spend 50 hours building a ship to have it blown up by pirates or other players on her first voyage.)As of Aug. 11 2015 Starmade-Procedurally generated world, it's never the same.-Takes imagination, or you can go download other player built ships.-When they say "open world" they mean, "open universe". Only limitations are your own imagination and creativity-Quite literally the universe is your sand box, build it, and they will come.-Save Yourself some time and learn how to use advaned build mode. (but first make sure you understnad how power works)-Oh yeah, there are ships and stuff... Did I meantion you can build whatever you want? (press "m" to spawn a station, press "x" to spawn a ship.)-Devs are super acive in the community, makes for easy vertical communication. Which is very refreshingThings to note:-Little bit of a learning curve.-Because code  for the game hasn't been streamlined perfectly yet there are some issues on multi-player servers due to lag when more than 15 players are on at one time. (this will effect game play severly)-The community, while for the most party very informed, is actually somewhat elitest (just something to note)-Pick the right server for your play style!! I can not stress this enough, it's very important that when playing for hundreds of hours on a server you at least like it a little bit.-Updates are rolling out all the time, as the game is in "alpha" (updates usually fix previous bugs but always bring with them their own new bugs, remember it's in "alpha")-I won't lie, it takes a very long time to get things done in starmade, however it is very rewarding creating your own empire.-If you want a perfectly polished game Starmade isn't quite there yet. But it still looks and feels awesome!Starmade is one of the best games I have ever played, a must have game.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is for explorers and builders. Elements for killers are still in the works. StarMade is like Minecraft, but in space, and it's still developing major components. Alone in a galaxy unless you join a server, you'll find yourself floating in space, with few resources and some tutorials you'll build your first ship. It's not bad. Perhaps it resembles your favorite ship such as Serenity or maybe a TIE Fighter, maybe an F22, it's crude but it can move around, salvage resources and perhaps fire a decent volly of antimatter projectiles. What then? Like any game, you go out and collect resources. Asteroids, planets, abandoned stations, remains of empires remain in an eerie setting of dead space. Space where planets are 12 sidded dice that orbit a star and all is your playground.Then, you're attacked by NPC Pirates. Maybe one, perhaps a dozen, they come in and blast you and your ship into dust. Like Eve and other games, it's not the end. You research, learn about cloaking devices, radar jammers, you can build a fleet of NPC ships and have some mine while others patrol. Construct robotic arms, configure logic blocks that make Minecraft redstone a childs toy...Then, you realize there are NPC factions, shops trade with one another in a breathing economy, Pirates blantantly travel and leave a wake of destruction. Factions expand their territory to dominate the galaxy. Suddenly, it's not so lonely. Things you had to mod Minecraft for, you get here. So whether it's flying your custom designed Stardestroyer launching various TIE ships to attack, bomb or mine, or quietly watch the factions rise and fight one another in a Romulan war bird, or even a Firefly class transport to haul goods from one shop to another for trade, you'll find it here. The people working on this game, want crew commands, colonies, in depth NPC interactions, 4x style layered faction collaberation. They want to play in a living universe of simple complexity, and it's around the corner.So if...Space Engineers is overwelming due to it's complexity and the requirements for a large ship is insaneNo Man's Sky is lonelyEmpyrion is great but... you want more customization and options and lets face it, larger ships and fleetsPlanet Engineers needs to venture into space (But the colony building is fun)Minecraft needs more than a strange plane of exsistanceStar Trek Online needs ship interriorsYou want to command a fleet like Battle Star GalacticaLike Elite Dangerous but the ships feel too similar or staleThen check out Starmade. It's a great creative outlet where you can do more with less, it's easy to pick up and interesting to master and a good place to relax overall.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is still in alpha, let alone Early access, but I will put my experience to your service.Overview:This game is a voxel-based space sandbox with a bunch of original content.In this game, you can build ships, and fully customize it with the hundreds of blocks at your disposition.If you feel like taking a true challenge, you can go on and build a space station.The game includes factions, and faction battles. Factions have absolutely no player capacity limit. You can easily end up with five hundred factionmates with you.Now, let's talk about the pros and cons.PROS:- Infinite procedurally generated space universe, countless galaxies, special stars, derelict stations... so much content to explore.- Ships are fully customizable, and can get really accurate thanks to the advanced building mode at your disposition.- No size limit, feel like building a 400 megatons titan ship ? Feel free to do so, this game doesn't restrict you one bit.- Full multiplayer support.- Full controller support.- Developpement team pays huge regard to community opinion. You are the key to a better StarMade.- Totally functional logic systems, you can finally make your 50 meters squared chip in space.- Factories, automation.- AI-controlled turrets and probes.- Awesome active community on the StarMade forums, and the StarMade registry.- So much pros, I surely forgot something.CONS:- Glitchy, that's to be expected of an Alpha.- Can crash on multiplayer... hope your ship was full-stoped before you did.- Tough on low-performance CPUs- Hard learning curve, you'd be best watching some tutorials on the web before throwing yourself in the game.- Larger ships are incredible stronger than smaller ships due to buffs in shield systems and weapon systems depending on number of blocks, more on that later.Now this game might be for €9.99, but it sure is worth twice as much, if I had one gift to do to a bored gamer, it would be this game.It has been on developpement for about 4 years (More, already ?), but is still progressing at a sustained pace. The community can't wait to see further progress, and neither can I.Ships will become overpowered exponentially with their mass, if one dreadnought is 50 megatons in mass, it will still be much stronger than 200 corvettes of 500 kilotons. This is due to the exponential increase in stats the more blocks you have connected in one array. This is sad because that can inhibate epic space fleet battles. Fighters will never be able to breach through larger ships due to the former having weak weapons compared to larger ships, and the latter having too much shield recharge rate for the former.Schema and the developpement team plan on upgrading this though, to make smaller ships stronger and more of a threat, and larger ships more exposed to swarms of smaller ships.I guess I'll take my leave, before this review scares other people.
