content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Starmade is everything you want in an epic Sci-Fi space builder sim, minus the shiny graphics and story.  1. Have an actual avatar 1st and 3rd person view, not just the inside of a cockpit 2. Build your ship/station/home world/mech in Creative or Survival modes 3. Create your faction/empire/rebel fleet  4. Travel from space to planet surface and back without load screens 5. Massive Universe...planets/sectors/solar systems/multiple galaxies...you will die of old age before exploring it all 6. Single player or Join one of many Worldwide Multiplayer Servers PVE/PVP/RP 7. Simple or complex Builds, your choice. With indepth logic blocks and functions for the dedicated builder 8. Advanced build mode with adjustable quantity line/plane/cube function, multi axis symmetry build, rotation etc. 9. Blueprints for saving creations, allowing you to respawn, trade, download from or upload to the community site10. Pre-existing NPC enemies and  AI modules so you can create your own enemies/allies...There is so much to this game that you really just need to try it. The possibilities are almost endless for those with a healthy imagination.Starmade is often compared to Minecraft graphically, though it has a much greater selection of block types available. Of course cubes are a given, it is voxel based afterall, but with wedges, corners and their variants your builds can be very sleek. This is the game you should graduate to when you get bored of Minecrafts limitations.If you simply can not deal with anything less than cinematic style realistic graphics then this game is likely not for you. Try out Empyrion or Space Engineers, both great games, but the trade off is you sacrifice the scope of the game environment.Sorry fans of Mass Effect and Half Life, but if you are looking for a deep engaging story with fully realized characters and plot, this is not your game.  But if you want to let your imagination loose and create your own story, your own universe alone or with friends then Starmade might be your flavour.  You will spawn into a universe with some inventory to get you going and a limitless expanse of space stretching out before you. If your first reaction is to look for someone to tell you what to do next, go back to the Steam Store and keep hunting, this is not your game.But if you see that epic expanse, and excitement fills your heart with the desire to explore, build and test the limitations of your imagination....welcome to the family!Basically put. When you were a child, if you saw a cardboard box and had a million ideas of what you could do with it and not one of them included storage, you will love Starmade.

number of helpful: 62 of 68 people (91%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'll begin by saying the amount of hours I have playing this game, according to steam, is in no way relevant, as the game was just moved to steam very recently. I've been playing starmade ALOT. I've seen this game constantly change every month with new updates, each one improving the overall experience dramatically. This is still an early release, and like any other early release, your experience is not a guarenteed satisfactory one. There will be bugs. You will get frustrated. But overall it is worth it. And like many others that have reviewed this game, I agree that Starmade is one of very few early access games that I'd be ok with calling a "full" game, even though it is still not officially released.  Despite the occasional crashing and glitches, it is a very enjoyable game. But it is also a sandbox game, which means it is whatever YOU want it to be.I would not call this a minecraft clone. Do not listen to anyone who says it is. I do believe one of the developers of the game mentioned they based it off of minecraft, but it is a totally different experience. Some people have tried comparing it to the minecraft mod galacticraft, but even that is totally inaccurate. Still, if I had to compare, I'd say starmade was a mix of Eve Online, Dayz, and yes, Minecraft. Building: The building mechanics in this game are EXTREMELY advanced, and surpass minecraft by a long shot. It has everything I wanted in minecraft and more. There is a symmetry mode when building a ship or space station, there is an "advanced building mode" (activated by holding down ctrl in build mode), and there is an option to build more than one block at a time, and choose how many blocks on each axis (x, y or z) you want to place at once. This is customizable in the config, though the default is a max of  10x10x10. On one server, you could build up to 50x50x50. Now if you use x, y and z symmetry (and you have enough blocks for it) you can build quite a large mass in one click (though I wouldn't recommend it due to the lag involved). There is also wedges, coming in I believe 4 different types, and a wide range of different colored blocks. Overall, the things you can do with build mode is just insane. Pvp: On many servers, they have an "anything goes" rule to pvp. Essentially, this feels alot like rust or dayz, or even EVE online.  People can easily betray you, destroy your ships and stations and then warp out of your star system before you even knew what happened. Due to a recent update, factions are now extremely important in controlling and maintaining multiple star systems in your galaxy. There is always a risk in forming an alliance with people you don't know, but it is usually worth it. I'd advise to keep some secrets, however. Don't go around the server bragging about your new ship, or how many credits you made in a recent raid on a pirate station. If you are in a faction with random people, try to keep a hidden storage box somewhere in a remote system with backup supplies in case the faction falls apart. As for the actual combat, it can get pretty chaotic. There's three really basic weapons, cannons, damage beams and missile blocks. Theres also effect modules and computers to modify your weapons. If you connect an explosive effect computer to a missile computer, it increases the missiles blast radius. Connecting an ion effect computer to a cannon computer decreases the enemy ship's power, useful for stopping the enemy from warping away from you or cloaking. Theres also blocks like the stop effect computer, which can stop a ship from moving completely.  The shield capacitor block gives your entire ship some shields that stop your actual blocks from recieving damage. The shield recharger will recharge your shields automatically (if you have enough power) after you take damage. The amount of customization means no two pvp battles are the same, everyone is constantly improving their ships and experimenting with different ratios to try and find the perfect balance between damage and manueverability, or power consumption and protection, etc. Mining and crafting: I can't say too much about this, as I haven't really experimented enough with the new crafting system. Mining was not very profitable before, it was too hard to find resources and the amount of work involved did not seem very worth it to me. Due to the new universe and faction update, as well as the new shop update, mining has become pretty much a neccessity if you're playing on a survival server. If you are in a system that your faction owns, you get a bonus amount of minerals when you mine a block. This does help quite a bit, and with enough people in your faction it shouldn't be too much of an issue. But if you're playing solo, don't expect to make a multi-million block ship anytime soon. The largest ship I've ever made was about 20 million blocks, though I mostly used credits to buy the blocks i needed in shops, as well as having a friend using the (very old) crafting system supply me with the rest.Also, NOTE: This game, for the time being, IS FREE TO PLAY! It has always been free to play. HOWEVER!!! Like when minecraft was in beta, this will only be temporary. When the game is finally released, the price will go up and you will no longer be able to play for free. Ignore the title "demo version", it is not a demo. You have full access to the game for free right now. But I highly suggest buying the game as soon as possible, as it is getting closer to release every day.YES, I do definately recommend this game. It is very fun, and somewhat easy to learn, but it can get pretty complicated and technical if you want it to be. I'm not really sure what else to say. More content is being added every month. It is unlike any other game I have ever played, in that you can really immerse yourself in the game and be that spaceship pilot you always wanted to be as a kid. There are an infinite number of planets to explore, asteroids to mine, stations to capture and/or blow up with missiles, pirates and bandits to kill, loot to grab, ships to build, alliances to form, enemy factions to destroy, and fun to have ^_^

number of helpful: 58 of 62 people (94%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								NOTE: I only play this game seriously in multiplayer.This game had me hooked from the moment I saw it released on steam. I had no prior knowledge to its existance, and I wish I had. The prospect of freely being able to build my own ship, and on top of that, exploring an almost infinite number of galaxies and systems, was one of the one things I have been searching for in a game.The good:The game runs like a dream, due to its blocky, basic style, yet looks great while doing so.Exploring the initial galaxy you spawn in is a blast, flitting between systems, mining for resources and credits, trying to work up enough money to repair that station you found, or to even build your own station from scratch, and exploring the mysterious wormholes that spawn in various locations in the galaxyShip combat is a blast, there ae multiple weapons systems, upgrades, and combinations to use to your advantage. Want a huge flagship that fire seeking rockets that move faster than any ship built? Sure thing! You want a tiny scout ship with the laser cannon capacity to rip apart said flagship with a few well placed shots? Doable! Warp drives take alot of the time out of flying at a constant speed of 75 kmph (max speed in my singleplayer games for some reason.)The plane setting ability allows for perfectly symmetrical building, perfect for making models of famous ships, like the sloppy Battlecruiser I spent hours on. Building in itself is also fun, as you get to explore what possibilities you have with weapons and defensive systems, along with the logic blocks they've added in. I'm still exploring the destructive capabilities of certain weapons themselves.The gray areas:Generating a planet takes ALOT of computing power, and my poor little Dell ♥♥♥♥♥ itself trying. "Get a better PC" yes, I'm aware. Money is limited, sir. And at the moment, I have none. Pirates steal blueprints from your catalouge, but when they start using a turret I designed for my flagship (a jumbled block of power generators, sheilds, and a seeker rocket array) to try and kill me and/or chase me down, (note: no thrusters are on said turret) it gets comical really fast.Stars, Pirate stations and Crabs often have MUCH to big of a range for their respective sizes. I was taking hits from a Prate station's turrets from 2 sectors away, hull damage from a star that was 3 sectors away, and a Crab found its way across an entire galaxy, flew into my space station, and buzzed of the little health I was rocking on, after I warp drived several times and used a wormhole to get away from the accursed station it was hiding in. The bad:Most Pirate turrets do RIDICULOUS ammounts of damage, especially to a new player only starting with 2.5k credits. Just asking that for new players' sake, tone it down a bit?Pirate stations have a nasty habit of generating in the sectors right beside the spawn shop, and even though it says you're protected, you can get endlessly spawnkilled.Money is a bit difficult to come by, especially when you need something the size of an aircraft carrier to be able to get away unscathed, and the factories require HUGE ammounts of resources to make shipbuilding materials. I know some servers have made it so that you start with large ammounts of money, but trying to play singleplayer can be downright infuriating at some points from the lack of knowledge new people might have, and lack of money/resources. A "peaceful" type of setting might be nice for this.On the rare occasion, I've had Crabs spawn inside my claimed and repaired station, and it gets to be very tedious patching holes in both my cruiser and my station.Other than the few issues I've seen, the game is amazing. I especially enjoy teaming up with other players in large battleships to take town a pirate base, and man, is that a blast. I hope the devs take even more interesting routes with this game, and make it even more fun!Cheers,UPDATE ADDITION:I can no longer play this game, because the laucher repeatedly crashes the game after loading the world i created. until i can successfully load up a world, i hate the game :>~Doge

content:
Posted: January 2
Early Access Review
								I've played for a "few" hours.  I've been a player, faction leader, and now I help run a server called Light vs Dark.Briefly:  The part about this game that I think separates it from similar games is that EVERYTHING is built block by block.  There is no "turret" block.  YOU build the turret.  Ever been playing MineCraft and wish you could build a spaceship and have massive battles in space?  Or maybe have a better build mode?  Well, StarMade might be for you then.  You can easily build massive structures and designs.  Battling can be fun, if you don't take it personally, and ALWAYS save a blueprint backup!Pros:  Building your own ships is fun.  If you like building aesthetically, you can.  Or if you want to roleplay, you can.  Combat with smaller ships can be a lot of fun with friends (and enemies).  If you want, build an empire and subjucate the universe to your power.  There are also *some* tools to do modding, like server wrappers, custom decorative blocks, and changing recipes.  AND best of all, you can try the full game for free and play for as long as you'd like.  Just download the demo or go to starmade.org and download it and create a free account.  If you want to support the game, definitely go buy it.  I got my money's worth for sure with thousands of hours played.Cons:  The playerbase has been going down lately, and a big part of what makes this game fun is playing with other people.   I run a server that used to have 30 people on it at a time, but now it's been quiet.  This is sad to see.  There are also bugs, since it's a rather small development team, but they do move at a surprising pace (if you compare it to how quickly MineCraft used to release updates).  Also, I should mention that this game isn't for everybody.  Many people will try it, die and fail, and quit.  Also, some players will create really intensely laggy ships and crash their games, so my suggestion is to build realistically sized ships or join a server with active admins who will help keep things running smoothly.When you play tips:  My suggestion to anybody is to team up with other new players when you try the game out.  Fly with friends and you'll have a much better time.  And do not take on powerful factions unless you want to get creamed.  But don't let the rating on steam discourage you from trying the game.  We could use the new players, and some of you will be like me, and enjoy the game for thousands of hours.  :)

Early Access Review
								first off I want to say do not take my word for it - just play the demo on a server with some people watch some youtube (I would recommend "Bench" clear speaking right to the point) about some of the things you can come up with and hey the demo's free and its like 300MBs of download - why not try it?so without further commentsso allot of people looking at this game compare it to minecraft or a simpler version of space engineers doing so however is a major lack of understanding - so to help clear things up does it use blocks and a voxel based world like minecraft? yes - the block based worlds are easier to build in and allow for more customization then solid pieces or snap to functions but the depth of creation from the varied blocks allow for many more then just cube designs  is it minecraft in space? no - the customization from the game allows linking systems and custom designs that range from space stations to a colony on planets  to ships of any shape or sizeis this space engineers simpler cousin?no - while space engineers I agree has some better graphics and a few cool factors allot of it is premade blocks - want a anti missile or anti player turret just build one drop it - what a anti missile turret in starmade? decide on weapons dozens of choices of what to shoot down missiles with then how many barrels do you want - is a cloud of shrapnel more important? or is it a stream of minigun fire - its your choice the entire turret is custom made - like the turret save it for later - don't like it rebuild it whats the big difference between space engineers and starmade? well the simple version is - starmades a game space engineers is a simulation - sure I know what your thinking whats the difference? a game doesn't let reality hold it down its meant to sit back and have fun on not determine if some angry newton lover is gonna blow you up for not useing the right real life science (seriously look it up they have a entire griefer based society that attacks people in space engineers for not using real science in construction of ships!) where as the community of starmade is far nicer and relaxed - people duel in pvp rather then stomp some noob - and the community you draw says allot about your gameso starmade sure it looks like other games - sure its a early access game - but what does that mean you get for 10 dollars?  (or 4 copies for 30 dollars meaning you and 3 friends can enjoy this game for the cost of 1 of the other 2 games) in short just about unlimited space sandbox - want massive carriers or a simple fighter or anything in between - want to work on a multiplayer game as a trader or ship builder or even a pirate - do it - the people are friendly and mostly fun to work with - the new rail system was a game changer and people are not mad about it but over joyed about rebuilding starmade is a gem in the rough at the moment and while they have a ways to go they already have more stuff to do then allot of 30+ dollar games out there that are finished so give it a try and you will not regret it if you love sandbox games

number of helpful: 52 of 56 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Starmade has been in development for a while, and it will be for a while longer. But updates are consistent, the core mechanics are solid, and the game already offers an ton of fun to those it caters to right now. But because it is still very much in development, a number of mechanics are still missing, meaning that for now it does cater to a more specific group. Namely the one that absolutely can't resist building creative things with a full suite of editing tools, blowing them up and strutting around in their creations in front of their fellow community members.The comparison to Minecraft is easily draw of course, and one should rightfully compare the two. However, even in mimicing some elements, the game always implements them in its own unique way, making it a breath of fresh air for some veteran MC players like me. That said, the implementation is usually more complex and intricate than its counterpart, so be prepared for a learning curve, thankfully often rewarded with the awesome result of your contraptions.For now, the worlds are pretty scarcely populated and static, meaning that if your desire is not to build and start exploring all sorts of wonderful places, you might be disappointed. A huge amount of content is planned, but it will take time, with the first of these updates hitting soon in the form of massively upgraded space stations. Interfaces and tutorials are also quite barebones for the time being. Very useful and functional once you get a hang of them, but harder to learn and slapped together in places. If learning isn't your sort of thing, move on for now.===================In short, the game already features a great amount of mechanics that can provide you with a lot of fun if you like building, warping & blowing stuff up in your own creations, but for now, lacks content and might seem intimidating to players just starting out.Good:- Full suite of building tools- Very optimised- Very scalable- Infinite universe- Procedural damage & debris- Innovative hexagonal planetsBad:- Improvised interface- Lack of explorable content- Steep learning curve- Unbalanced economyIf you have any sort of creative or adventurous spark to you, definately try it and start creating or join a world without limits!If not, maybe skip it and check back in another 6 months or so for the next batch of updates.

content:

Early Access Review

With the incredible amount of features already implemented, it's easy to forget that this is just an alpha. If you really like it, buy it. But if early-access games and alpha games frustrate you, or maybe if you are really young and do not understand computers, go ahead and just get the demo.

Early Access Review
								I've played this game since it's very earliest days, since the days.  I love this game and most of my best friends I have met because of this game, but I cannot for the life of me actually recommend it to anyone, but I can't really say I discourage people from playing it either. and don't let my steam Record fool you, I have a LOT more hours in this game than it lets on. as I have been playing before this game came to steam.The game feels like it's in development hell.  they keep shoveling out broken updates, which sometimes breaks old stuff.  fix it with duct tape. sends it back out rinse and repeat.  there are some problems from years ago they still have yet to fix.and they only seem to fix it when it is so broken that they are forced to fix it. lest there are riots in the streets.it is actually smarter to keep your server outdated for a few days when a new update drops than gamble with it and risking everyone who plays on your server being royally angry. ESPECIALLY if it may do weird things to the universe.The player base is dying.  people are leaving, people are losing interest. a new broken update hits, players spike for a little bit, but when that's all said and done, it starts dropping again.  servers like the one I play on are getting less and less players joining, and as a result are dead, or dying.personally I can't play it anymore.  I had a good run, and I got my 14.99 out of it x1000 times over.If you think you can still have fun with it despite the warnings I've given you, power to you.  Give it a shot, you might love it as well.  if you got friends to play with you fantastic!  I hope your times playing this game are great.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have hundreds of hours in this game and yet I had to sit here for a few minutes to just decide what I was going to say about StarMade. In short, it is completely overwhelming. I spawned into my server and did the tutorial..... twice. I then realized how poorly made the tutorial is and proceeded to go find youtube videos on how to get started. This helped tremendously and I returned to the game ready to become a space exploring master. I quickly built my first little ship and flew to a shop to buy some more parts with my starting credits. I had my first mining ship ready to go in a little over an hour and from that point the game has only gotten more awesome. I soon lost my first ship to a wave of rogue pirates and had to start over. I was upset but it taught me the simple truth that space is not a friendly utopia. My next ship was still a mining ship but I equipped weapons, light armor, and some shields to ensure my long worked for investment would not be lost again. I now have some friends on the server with me and we have all started building capitol ships, cruisers, and stations. The game's building system is the most wonderful thing I have experienced in a "voxel" style game. The ability to mirror on all 3 axes, bulk block place, free rotation camera, copy/paste options, undo/redo buttons, and template saving/loading are just a few of the functions this game offers IN ALPHA. You can even save/upload ship templates from the registry or your computer into the game server for purchase and building! I could not ask for a more appropriately envisioned building system. If you see the reviews stating the game has a steep learning curve, they would be right. But don't let that dissuade you from grabbing a copy for free while in alpha! Its free, what do you have to lose other than some time? It is definitely worth a look at least.The controls are a bit clunky but that is because the range of motion and movement directions and ship menus are so plentiful they had to map nearly every key on the keyboard to a button. It takes some getting used to especially the getting around in 0G part. The game is buggy and occasionally runs out of memory or has a java fatal exception. Its an EARLY ACCESS title and to expect perfection is just not realistic. It isn't even that common of an event honestly.  Even with the few negatives I've mentioned above this game is still unreal. The scope and size is just absurd. I looked at my first galaxy where I spawned in and realize it would take months to explore all of those stars. Then I found several neighboring galaxies and the realization dawned..... YOU ARE SO TINY AND INSIGNIFICANT. You are a speck of dirt in one solar system, in a galactic neighborhood with thousands of other solar systems, in a galactic cluster containing thousands of galaxies, in a universe containing thousands of galactic clusters..... It blew my mind to see the scale on the map. Sure it sounds "big" when its written out in text or as you see the stars from in the game. But opening that galactic map.... it is so overwhelming. TL;DRIf you want an overwhelming space experience, like building spaceships, want something different from many other games on the market, and are willing to accept and understand what EARLY ACCESS means, then please download the demo and get started. I chose to purchase a 4 pack of this for myself and some friends not long after getting the demo version. It is that good.  I don't do this often, but if you would like, add me and I would be happy to help walk you through some of the basics. I have several private servers up and running on US East Coast including one to provide a slightly safer "new player" friendly environment.

Early Access Review
								I have 300+ hours off of steamEdited on 1/12/16, Currently version 0.19538The first thing you need to know is that for now you have to accept change, many things are changing currently. My opinions are based off of the current state.PROS Amazing building Bi-weekly Updates Varied Gameplay Clever Building Mechanics, blocks have more than one use Endless space; no loading screens or pauses Multiple procedural stations designs Customizable ship based weapons Customizable ship engine properties Commandable AI fleetsCONS Can be difficult and time consuming There are some balance problems, especially with combat Server stability problems, but definately playable Some glitches and exploits, but not many are gamebreaking Not very moddable yet; but official mod API is planned Ship movement is more like a mobile turret than a traditional sci-fi shipStarMade vs Space Engineers+Less laggy, slower computers can run it granted you have at least 4 gigs of ram+SM is more akin to the X or freelancer series while SE is more like Garry's Mod*+SM is free for the time being, the SM demo is the same as the full version+Custom weapons and some custom tools+SM ships can have moving parts that are reliable+SM has player controled AI ships X3 style+Soon to have complex ai factions to fight and trade with-SE has far better superficial graphics*-SE has far better animations regarless of style*-SE feels clunkier and less responsive*-SM planets and asteroids are very small compared to SE*opinion based on the time I spent playing both gamesThis has been my first detailed review but I thought it was the least I could do for such an amazing game with such amazing devs.Thanks for reading

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR at the end.So I have been playing Starmade for quite some time, clearly. With this review I will attempt to tell yall why I have nearly 1000hrs in this game.I love it. I hate it. Never have I come across a game that can enrage me as much as this yet I still play it. I could not tell you how many times I stopped myself from punching my screen and snapping my keyboard in half just because I knew that if I did, I would not be able to play anymore. Minecraft never got my attention any more than "oh, that looks neat". The idea of building a house and then what? Oooooo I have a house or a village or a Grand Castle! Good for you! Now what does it do? What do you do with it? That does not capture my intrest. You know what does? I can build a Grand Castle, pack it full of power generators, shields, engines and 'frikkin laser beams to go blow up anything I come across in the Galaxy.Not all is fun and games in the 'verse though. There are issues. Glitches and bugs and bad coding, Oh My! Sometimes your turrets will teleport themselves halfway across the sector. Sometimes your ship wont fully load and it looks like you are missing half of it. Weapons 99% of the time work great, 1% of the time, they work about as good as a screen door on an airlock. Yes, the Devs are very active. They do listen to the players. Updates rather often. Unfortunatly, the updates do kinda break the game sometimes. But, they get patched, things are a little wonky for a few days, then its back. All is good.I couldnt tell you how many new people Ive seen pop in on a server and start screaming "sum 1 halp me! I haz the dumb n dnt knw what 2 do!!!!!" And when nobody responds because we are all too buisy with our brain cells commiting seppuku, they get butt hurt and leave without ever playing the game. Look, play the Tutorial, watch YouTube vids, get yourself into a good Faction. For the love of (insert desired religious icon here) dont type in general chat with "L337 speak" or "Millennial texting shorthand"! Take your time, learn the game, I can almost promise you that you will enjoy it.TL;DR----You like Space Engineers? Good for you, this is better. You like Minecraft? You need to upgrade.You like Eve? Cool, so did I. Get this instead.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								In case you missed it: DEMO IS FULL GAME. DOWNLOAD DEMO = FREE FULL GAME (currently)If you want to make startrek/wars/whatever replicas this game is incredible. It has hands down the best tools for building in any voxel game i've seen; copy/pasting sections, placing large lines/circles/boxes/cylinders with ease, saving and loading ships/turrets/drones is quick once you know how, and building basic ships is extremely easy; only more advanced design aspects like weapon slaving, logic and moving components really require looking up information online. There are also tools for importing and exporting ships as 3D models. In addition the engine's performance is quite solid, i'm on a 5 year old machine and it can still handle 500m ships duking it out, 100s of drones or mining ships eating entire asteroids in one go. It has problems in some cases, like thousands of homing missiles, but it's generally well optimized with a few hiccups still in the game.So why, with all these great things and 2000 hours ingame am i not recommending this?Every single mechanic in the game is a broken mess. All the weapons are imballanced, to the point where of the 300+ weapon combinations only about 5 are actually useful. As far as survival/progression goes the game has nothing to do. You can create any item in the game in a few minutes at most from starting out, and once you get larger miners going resource collecting is utterly trivial. All the factories in the game are made from generic materials or bought for 1% of your starting money so forget about making any kind of intricate factories. And it's been like this for 2 years now.The game is early alpha and these things would normally be expected to be fixed later, but the developers seem to have no idea where they're going with the game, focusing on large procedurally generated universes (where did we see this before...) and pointless ship cosmetics instead of actual gameplay.If you just want to build stuff, it's a great game.If you want to do anything with the stuff you build, you're ♥♥♥♥ed.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								*DEMO VERSION = FULL GAME = FREE = YOU SOLD ME ON THIS GAME = HAPPY!*First: A Review about the Price / Demo / Free Thing:Other game companies vying for attention in the "Early Access" Arena (huge competition there) should take note of what StarMade has done with their business model. They are offering the full version of the game as a "Demo" for Free. Yes Free. You can play it as much as you want now, during Alpha - and then decide to buy. I don't know of many other Early Access games that are doing this ... in fact many of them are asking 25 to 40 bucks or more just to play a buggy Alpha version of their game with no guarantee they're going to keep developing or finish the game. I don't really like those odds and I have thrown money into Early Access games that are now collecting dust in my Library because the devs just stopped working on it.  StarMade is asking a very low price of 10 bucks right now ... that's less than you probably pay to go see a movie! DO IT. This price won't last. When the game grows in popularity and is more developed, that price will go up. This is smart marketing. Rather than asking a big up-front price for the Alpha and then slowly lowering that price via sales on Steam over time, these guys are smart. Ask NOTHING up front (Free Full Version / Demo) and a very small buy-in price. I'm impressed! Steam 'works' because players read reviews, players look at what's popular and selling fast in Early Access ... so asking a low up front price or even better, letting us play it FREE will get this game a lot of attention and fast. Now - The Game Review - Worth It?YES - YES - YES.This game is really solid for an early access game and has a lot more functionality and items than I was first expecting. I did not think it would have so many building parts and that exploring would be limited or simplistic in looks but WOW was I wrong.This is Minecraft-In-Space! Graphics - The textures, colors and graphics are awesome - better than most minecraft texture mods.Crafting - Gathering resources is easy and fun -- no blocks dropping off into space or down holes ... just ZAP and it's in your inventory. Putting bits together is easy and though the GUI for the crafting screen is still pretty rudimentary, it's intuitive enough you can get it easily.*EDIT* (Dec 11th) - After playing this a lot more over the past 4 days, I have come to realize the crafting system in StarMade is actually very complex (deceptively simple looking at first) and takes some learning to get the hang of (videos by other players helped) - so don't be fooled by the simple Minecraft look - it's a lot more indepth. There are factories of varying levels and power supplies must be maintained, and parts for your ships must be manufactured and assembled in a more complex way than I first realized. Again, I am very surprised at how much complexity they've already put into such an early Alpha game. StarMade's been in the works for quite a few years and it shows with how polished the crafting system is. If you were afraid it would be too 'simple' then let me reassure you this crafting system will challenge even the most detail-oriented game crafters.Tutorial - The Tutorial is very indepth and helpful (needs a little grammar / typo work - hey I'm for hire!) ;). I would advise doing the tutorial and then watching some player guides on youtube before you really start building your ship because it's somewhat tricky at first to get all the blocks in the right arrangement for a power efficient and secure ship while at the same time making it look good.Ships - Building your ship is pretty simple once you get the hang of the control blocks and such. Again, do the tutorial! I've looked at some of the amazing creations others have made online (videos and screeshots) and am very impressed at the unique and endless possibilities for your ship creations. Imagine if some of the insane things you've seen built in Minecraft could lift off and fly through space!Combat - I have done only a little of this so far being a newbie - but it seems solid and the options to upgrade and customize your ship's weapons is indepth and varied ... the crafting nuts who love space games (EVE Online?) will love this! There are shields and jammers and turrets and all the usual spacecraft type combat arsenals.Exploration - Flying around is a joy and the controls are so simple even my 5 year old can do it and loves it. Radomly picking a direction and heading off into the great unknown of space for some far off sector of the galaxy is really fun and relaxing too. There's some good 'Explorer-zen' in this game.Vast Universe - The Galaxy Map is pretty amazing too. I'm still trying to sort out navigating it but having a great time buzzing about the starter galaxy to get the hang of it. Scrolling out to see the sheer immense (infinite) size of the Universe was pretty mind boggling the first time!Planets! - Last but certainly not least - The PLANETS.  O-M-G. I was absolutely stunned the first time I entered the atmosphere of my first planet and took a look at the amazing creation before me. The physics are well done and the geometric shape of the planet is fun and so very minecraft-esque! *Edit* Planets are "Dodecahedrons" technically! The planets actually slowly rotate and it's such a fun feeling to bounce around on them, explore and gather minerals and such. Definitely my favorite part so far.Summary (TLDR): THIS IS MINECRAFT-IN-SPACE ... DO IT!!

Posted: April 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								<[PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS GAME'S FULL VERSION IS FREE THROUGH THE DEMO UNTIL APLPHA IS OVER]>Now that that small fact that most people miss ENTIRELY is over, let's get down to the review. My hours spent are fairly low in comparison to most of my other games, but I also spend quite a bit of time on the standalone version. Yes, you can download the standalone through the Starmade.org website. If you buy it here, you can link accounts and have full version there, aswell. Actual features time.+ The vistas you see in space are absolutley breathtaking.+ Massive ships are made far easier to build using the Advanced Build Mode tools. Size sliders, anyone?+ The community so far has been great. The skin system was fully released and fixed recently, so now you can make your astronaut look however you like.+ Best weapons customisation I have seen in block cannons by far. You can slave systems to other systems to create combo weapons, such as seeker missiles or rapid fire cannons.+ Great factions system, and while teh new chat took some getting used to, it's quite a bit better than the last one. (Messages scroll in the proper direction now)+/- You can make amazingly huge ships, all it takes is time and dedication. However, these large ships can be laggy.- Coded in Java, some users will experience issues.- Still has some major bugs, but I havn't encountered any that have truley broken my game.And that's about it on what I have to say. I would LOVE to see more texture packs from the community, and rotating blocks and joints would be amazing aswell. All in all, it's a good space battle and space ship building game.[EDIT]: Just updated a few days ago, and the game is probably 50% better than it was before because of the new Rail system. Easy docking, the ability to move ships on rails... it's a beautiful thing. No more annoying docking boxes!

Early Access Review
								WARNING: IF YOU HAVE AN INTEL DRIVER ON YOUR COMPUTER, THIS WILL NOT START WITHOUT SOME FIDDLING AROUND.If you're like me, you have an Intel card and a Nvidia card. To get this to launch correctly, you must open your Nvidia control panel and go to "manage 3D settings". Once there, click on the program settings tab, and find Starmade in the drop first drop down. Then click on the second drop down and find  the High-Preformance NVIDIA proccessor option. Then click apply, exit, and run Starmade!As for other ghraphic cards, I have no idea. I've only ever used NVIDIA so I wouldn't know :/As for the game itself, lots of fun! Its kinda like Starbound 3D. You build awesome space ships, fight pirates, gather resources, and even land on 3D planets with their own gravity!All in all, if this game starts it is alot of fun. :D

Early Access Review
								I first started playing this years ago, when it was just starting out and was far rougher than it is now. What I had when I first started playing:- Hull blocks (I don't think I even had wedges, now they have corners, tetras, and others)- Blocks make power.- Cannons go pew pew and damage stuff.- Missiles go boom boom and blow stuff up.- Some other really basic things like shields.- Random stations here and there (all the same, some had pirates)- No main menu, just a launcherWhat we have now:- 3 different types of hull (hull, armor, advanced armor) with different shapes of blocks.- A bunch of new weapon systems.- All weapons systems can have effects added to them, like punch-through and explosive effect.- CHEWIE GET US OUTTA HERE! (Jump drives)- CHEVRON 1 LOCKED (Warp gates)- Plenty of random spawn stations- A GUI that doesn't make me want to rip my eyes out.- An actual main menu that works pretty well.Along with so many other things I won't fill up this post with. You get the idea, this thing may as well be a new game from when I first started. We're still getting updates (Last one as of this post was 9/9/16, before that was 8/28/16), and the developers actually seem to listen to the players. (Check the most recent update notes). Don't forget it's FREE in alpha, so you have nothing to lose! TRY IT!

content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								WARNING: If you want to build cool♥♥♥♥♥♥& venture across the universe w/ buddies this game IS NOT FOR YOU.To issue this game a bad review is no easy task for me, it was a favorite for a very long time and I clung onto the hope that things would be developed in a direction that continued to interest me--unfortunately this is not the case.PROS:- Build system is better than Minecraft or ANY other block based sandbox in EVERY ♥♥♥♥ING WAY. (This absolutely 100% includes jokes like Space Engineers and Empyrion). NOTE: Having now played Avorion, I can no longer stand by this comment. StarMade's srongest point is building and it does a great job, but it is outclassed by the ability to scale and skew blocks in Avorion.- If you love redstone in Minecraft, StarMade's logic system will blow your mind.- ITS IN SPACE!CONS:- Insanely long "alpha" cycle. 6 years?- Development direction appears geared toward singleplayer and RTS [elements], very unfortunate.- There is still very little content to actually enjoy or play.- Remaining community would rather reject you than hear criticism. #fanboy- Developer neopotism. Don't ask about that Tomino guy.- Developer response to criticisms from community, "♥♥♥♥ off and make your own game."- Buggy as ♥♥♥♥, as in while rare its possible to loose ALL of your work if you don't quadruple backup everything up always. ..and that's just the tip of the ice berg.- Complicated systems: Many of the systems in the game are overly complicated to new players; from power efficiency to display tech, there is much here to overwhelm and send them running.- Engine cannot handle its own damage calculations for multiplayer combat, too many missles crashes servers.- Engine forever locked into java because lead dev made it himself--really amazing, but sucks at the same time: In example, distribution of damage calculations leading to client instability in a multiplayer setting.- Added RTS elements, such as: fleets, micromanaging fleet control, NPC factions, NPC fleets, NPC fleets controlling territory. More planned and publicly acknowledged micromanagement elements such as crews. These elements may be appealing to some, not me. It is also my opinion that they are the wrong direction given some of the aforementioned areas the engine falls short.- Dwindling playerbase.RIP StarMade. Loved you long time.You had more potential than all the unity survival clones combined and it has been squandered.These statements constitute my opinions and experiences based on years of playing this game, becoming one of the more established twitch streamers of this game, becoming one of the more established builders in the greater community of this game and finally being elected by the community twice to serve on a community council to work with the developers of this game. I resigned my second term over qualms about council activity (foremost amongst other things like these criticisms), leading to other resignations, a reformation of the council and eventually the temporary disbanding of that organization. I backed away from the community and game for many reasons, however, to date I am unable to elaborate on all of the reasons behind this because of NDA. The visibility of this review has been toggled off and on due to harassment and I will continue to remove comments inciting or participating in flame war as well as those making baseless and uninformed accusations or insults against me; such as stating that I never was on the council long enough to even be under NDA and thusly am full of♥♥♥♥♥♥or that my opinion that development feels decidedly inclined toward RTS and SP is some grand conspiracy to make the developers look bad. While the lead developer has stated the game is not going to be an RTS, I have criticized its RTS elements here and my intent has never been to convince people it is something it is not, an RTS--something the developer's and fanbase should try for a change. The spam posting and harassment speak volumes of some of my criticisms about what has gone wrong with this title. ..and now, this: https://xkcd.com/1357/

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								The most accessible space building game yet.I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the theme of space. I've spent a few hours on this game with a friend of mine, she and I trecked through space in what could only be described as a "Miner's Life". Due to the game being far from complete, it is without question that methods of income are highly limited. The game begins you off with only a few blocks, the essentials for a hopeful star-merchant or space-hero, the basic thrusters, some cannons, a core for your ship, power supply blocks and some armors. Being a new-found space explorer, it is without question that chasing down pirates it THE stupidest thing you can attempt. ( Although it may be possible to successfully bring down a pirate at the start. )Each system is a bit complex but it doesn't mean they are impossible for beginners to learn.Power System suggestion: DO NOT CLUMP YOUR POWER SUPPLIES! It's ineffective.The way the power supply works, I found it highly effective to line your system up in two 1 x X (X being any number you can afford ) lines that are spaced by one block each. So your systems would look like this:--------------------------------------------------   Each dash being power blocks.I'm not adept enough to figure out how the weapons systems work but from my research they're highly ineffective when clumped. I've seen a lot of suggestions stating that thirty cannon block separate and independent of each other are far more effective than all of them combined. Making bigger cannons practically useless.Also included in this game is a crafting system which I have not personally tested, it allows for the mined raw materials to be crafted into processed variants.Also worth noting: Each star CAN be approached. It's a matter of designing a ship that won't be obliterated by the time you reach it. Planets can be approached as well and even be built on to house a base or landing dock for the miners and would-be pirates.There are still a lot of systems that are implemented that I haven't even touched. A lot being complex or lacking an updated guide. For example: Turret systems, boarding systems, in depth power supplies, and as I've said before, weapons sytems.It is a game worth checking out and I highly suggest trying it with a friend.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								There are many block building games and clones, and from the screenshots and videos of Starmade you may feel that this is just another one. I caution you to not fall into this line of thinking and give Starmade a chance. As of this writing, the game is completely free to play and downloadable from the developers website during it's alpha period.Is it Minecraft in space? No. It's a starship game with a block building motif.Like many people cutting their teeth with block building games, I felt restricted. Even with mods and redstone advancement I felt my creations were static and dead. I felt any attempts to construct creations of grandeur were less not a matter of creativity but more overcoming the limitations that the game enforced. Resource management and collection was more of a hinderance than anything, and I spent more time micromanaging furnaces than playing the actual game.With Starmade I felt free to explore and expand in any way I chose. Even in survival mode the pursuit of expansion seemed more rewarding and the progression of my ships was smooth. The game developers provided basic tools (admittedly with a bit of a learning curve) throughout to make sure that you are able to build and play the game fast. You spend less time flying around collecting materials as asteroids with resources are plentiful and respawn throughout the galaxies. Automation, factories, logic, and filtering sort your materials the way YOU choose. Building tools that mirror and place blocks in bulk, with in-game guides make it fast and easy to lay down your ship designs. Blueprints and shipyards make saving your designs and testing out new things a breeze.Any aspect of the game of interest to you? Focus on it! You can go as big or small as you want. Build planet-sized mining rigs, or quick-rapid fire fighter craft... or make small stealth ships to just explore the universe. Best of all, the developers and community are in constant communications... sharing ideas and opinions, fixing bugs and adding enhancements to the game constantly. The list of upcoming features is fantastic and after watching it's development for years I have yet to see them cancel or reject a truly anticipated feature.Starmade is one of the few games that I allowed myself to fall into because I felt there were no limits.I played for three years, primarily before it was Greenlit. Starmade was the one game I could always come home to. It became my favorite game to play anytime I had free moment. Sadly, I am writing this review now only as I am parting ways with it.Space, by it very nature, is empty. When you are lacking content you have to make your own fun, and it's hard playing multi-player games alone. It is true there are quite a few Starmade servers with players on 24/7, but the current state of the game does not encourage teaming up with those who may be untrustworthy. Factions are available though somewhat limited at the time of this writing, and there are no 'personal' access blocks. That being said, I can't get a single one of my gamer friends interested in playing Starmade.I am not a game developer and will not attempt to act as if I know the solution, but when I demo Starmade to my friends from the ground up all they see is the void of space and not much else. In most survival games the start is a mad rush to get yourself equipped and protected as soon as possible. Your first dirt hut is an amazing achievement. In Starmade, you may as well never even leave the starting shop if you so choose. There is no call to action, no shove out the door, no impending doom, nothing making a new user wish to 'do' anything.I believe in Schine (the developers of Starmade).  I have no doubt that with their efforts and the support of the existing fan base they will absolutely polish and shine Starmade into a diamond. I just don't know how long that it will take. With that in mind, it's time for me to dock my ship for now, shut down the reactors, mothball the factories, and close up shop.So long, and thanks for all the fish.Edit: Note - As of Jan 16th, 0.19549 personal blocks have been added. I will update my review further when I come back to the game.

Early Access Review
								Ah StarMade.First off this is a fantastic game... don't get me wrong, so much potential, such a wonderful concept being brought to life! BUT and yes that is a big, big but.There are some very serious issues with performance when it comes to loading planets.... like game dropping out issues, even when everything is turned to low it still does not help.I honestly cannot get near most of them because they are too big and it causes a critical error. And no it isn’t my pc as I am running decent hardware.Being Alpha I understand we are bug testing. So I am not angry as such, more disappointed at something that shouldn’t have even been an issue in the first place, the description says this game is built to run on older PC's and I am telling to right at this very moment this would not run on an older PC if my rig cannot handle it.I recommend this game to those who are interested but I warn any who purchase that there will be that optimization issue that stops players from exploring some planets.So devs:1. Fix optimization issue2. actually start us out on a planet and not right next to a space traging post where we can basically build a ship straight away.3. fix descriptions as some of them don't even exist yet also there are spelling mistakes in a few of them.Thats pretty much all I can think at this point in time, I will be sure to update you on gameplay and any other issues that in find :) Keep up the good work!**EDIT**Okay so for those who are also experiencing any issues with planets loading, I have found that if you get to the point where the planet just starts to load, press esc, alt+tab and do something else for 5 mintues while it loads.Helped me get to a planet that actually crashed my game several times :)**EDIT UPDATE**So after another hour or 2 I have managed to get a fair amount of materials, storage and am starting to build a large enough ship to hopefully raid a pirate station (hopefully), I have a homebase with its own spawn point and am slowly but surly working towards my own station!Gameplay and performance seem to get better as you get further through the game, maybe that's just y patience improving.... I don't know haha.Overall this game really has me wanting to play more and more with every second I play it. SO with that being said I give it a 10/10 rating (y)

Early Access Review
								This is the game i have been searching for for nearly my entire life. I like a few things in specific: Strategy, Sandbox, sci-fi, Factions, and community. I tried Eve Online, but the subscription♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. I tried Minecraft, but it was too basic. I tried Starbound, but it's only 2d and doesn't have depth. THIS fits all the rules. You start as a character with essential supplies and you just need to survive. Single Player can be boring, but the multiplayer servers make this game live up to its potential. Make alliances, kill space pirates, build ships, watch them get wrecked, build better ships, wreck the ships that wrecked yours, and explore in an almost (if not) infinite universe. And about worrying about people taking your precious supplies or looting your corpse? Don't worry, When you die you keep your inventory, and in a faction you can choose one planet/space station where NOBODY can steal your stuff. Join this ever-expanding community today and learn the arts of the explorer, the empire builder, the captain, and the Warrior. I highly reccomend this game to anyone who likes the genres i previously stated.

content:
Posted: February 27
Early Access Review
								Starmade, to be overly reductive, is Minecraft in space.Starmade is a voxel-based space game that takes place in a procedurally generated universe.Players have complete freedom over what to build and do.PROS:1.)When I say you can build anything, I mean anything. The various block shapes allow for more diverse shapes than a fully cubic world would allow. Functional blocks also make your designs have a purpose that extends beyond the aesthetic.2.)The developers stream Tuesday and Thursdays 4-6 EST, and communicate with the community heavily. The fact that you can play the game for free is testament to the fact that the dev team actually values creating a great game (not to mention how long its been in alpha!).3.)There are a whole host of multiplayer servers, and customizing the servers to suit a group's playstyle is easy. Sector length, mining yield, what ships pirates use, and so on are all completely customizable in server configs. 4.)Being able to actually build functional ships brings a sense of purpose to any construction project. Your ship isn't just a centerpiece, it's a colossal avatar of destruction/stealthy perma-cloaked spy/kingpin of the mining industry. Each block has its own contribution to the whole.CONS:1.) When playing multiplayer, lag and latency are issues, particularly for people with lower-end CPUs. Large collisions, overlapping spawns, or interacting with planets really at all will lag servers enormously. However, the devs do work to solve performance issues, just recently releasing a patch that nearly eliminated online lag with large amounts of missiles on screen.2.) Any story is self-made. To the credit of the devs, space is a busy place, with various factions fighting it out and trading with the player. It's unfortunate that interactions with factions does not go beyond that. Randomly generated quests, or even some preset ones in combination with some simple lore would do a great deal to flesh out the single-player experience. However, this game/genre isn't really supposed to have an engaging story-line. Those looking to be immersed in a single-player story should look elsewhere.3.) Arguably, there are some balancing issues (no reason to use pulse weapons; what is a warhead). However, the game is still in alpha and the devs do change the balance in the game frequently in order to find the right mix. 4.) Though the complex nature of the building system keeps the game interesting and adds an element of skill through optimization of ships, the lack of any real, advanced guides in game hold back new players from learning much. Also, due to the rapidly changing nature of the game, youtube tutorials often can be quickly outdated (docked power, weapon rebalancing, how shields and turrets work).If you are a fan of creative construction, then the pros clearly outweigh the cons. For those looking to recreate their favorite ships, fly them around the galaxy, and terrorize pirates, this is your game. The Mulitplayer community is mostly friendly, or at least active and passionate about the game, and playing online in a faction is a lot of fun. Once this game is fully balanced, optimized, and released, I completely expect it to be a wonderful experience online. For now, I would rate Starmade a 7/10. It has all the right tools to be a paragon of the creative genre, but is held back by low popularity and performance issues. Once more people can and are playing Starmade, I would rate it 9/10 for people who enjoy these types of games. Definitely a great game, and I encourage anyone who can to contribute to its development process. Those who simply want to try it out always have the option of playing the entirety of the game for FREE as well.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is to address the people having performance issues. I'm running on an older i7 2600, with 8gb of ram. I have no FPS or lag problems whatsoever, unless some asshat in a 2km ship is trying to breed with a planet.First, make sure you know your computer specs, I recommend having at least:6gb of system memoryi5 3450. GTX550 or equivilant	If you use intel graphics, dont. Save yourself the pain.1: 1 GB of ram allocated is NOT enough for this game, get 64bit java and increase it immediately in the launcher (options > memory settings) - I use 6gb normally, but you should be okay allocating 3-4.2: Disable shadows to greatly increase your FPS, it is highly inefficient currently, and unless you mod the game, the draw distance sucks.3: There are lots of options available, only mess with the ones you know, if you want to find out what something does, go here https://starmadedock.net/chat/ log in and ask the community - we're mostly helpful.4: If the tutorial hates you, and you can't complete it, again go to the above link and ask the community! We will be happy to help.As for the game itself, it's incredible fun, if you like building ships, the largest ship you can build without rendering going wonky is about 4072m long/high/wide, with the core being placed in the center.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Oh starmade... This game is quite addicting.So looking at this you might think, hmm a minecraft clone, but in space... But that's not fair to Starmade. About the only similarities with Minecraft are that it is block based, Java and is focused on building.Starmade is all about building. Building factory setups, building ships, making stuff bigger and better. It has a lot of tools to help you do this with symmetry planes, a slider to select a number of blocks to place at once, advanced filtered block removal/replacing and so on.A big part of Starmade is putting systems together. Whether the be their excellent logic system, the power system, or weapon systems. They are all quite interesting and give a lot of different interactions.My only real complaint with the game is that it is rough around the edges. There is a lot of depth of building and blocks and system interactions, but the NPC system is practically non-existent. There is little reason to explore and the Pirate ships are incredibly outdated with many models that simply don't work.However, these are EA complaints. I expect it to be a bit rough. They've made great strides in the last year and I'm hoping this next development leg starts to fill out the content gap.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
Early Access Review
 Disclaimer - I have been gifted a free key for this game for review purposes, however my review will be kept as truthful as possible, since I am meant to help developers and buyers/gamers.  StarMade v.0194  Overview'Starmade is a new take-on to the genre of Space exploration and building. I love both of those things, I believe that many people can agree with me too. It has many, many, many different items for buildings well, basically anything you want. A Battleship/Starship Destroyer? Why not. A space-station? Sure. Basically a ship which is OP (loads of energy storage, very fast regeneration of energy, tons of shields and shield regen ect)? Go ahead. This game is saying "go ahead, build anything, even the most complicated, most awesome looking ship, with a station on a planet, which is icy and next to a giant handmade tree" and does it very well with its limitations (you can make a lot of things, when I say a lot, I mean more than [insert large number here]. GraphicsThe graphics are very impressive, especially for Early access. There's lens flares, realistic lighting, tons of graphical settings (such a very high FoV of 30-110!) There are resolutions higher than 1920x1090, which I have not seen a lot of in games. The maxinum View distance is very amazing, even on the '10000'  of '20000' setting, I can see way further than I would even need too. I have a load of fps even on the higher settings, which I would not have of though since the game is this beautiful. Heck, you can even choose between pixely or realistic looks! So tihs is highly rated for this catergory, and it's well earned. What StarMade has to offer Explore, build, trade with others, buy from others, colonize planets, make factions, play with others, command a fleet, become a god, create a money factory, mine asteroids, blow up planets, and so much more. Pros and Cons Pros:Advanced in graphicsExcellent use of engine featuresSo many possibilitesTons of optionsMultiplayerCheap enoughCons:Mirror mode options are confusing Recommendation? Well, I guess it's a hard game to get the grips of, but it's for most age groups. Starmade is educational and actually very  fun. It helps teaching about space, basic star-ship building and much, much more. This is a mini Space Engineers if you will. It's a quickly developing game that has yet to see its true light of day in the Steam Store since it's one of the most hidden gems on the Store. Maybe it's due to lack of sales for Starmade, or because the developers don't want to make a game with little-to-no bugs in itself available to the whole of Steam. Anyway, Space Engineers is a very similar game with just a bit more depth. Both games are great and I will soon review SE. Final Rating A clean 8.5/10 - Worth for everyone  I have been gifted the key by the kind developers of the game. They make my reviews about games like this possible.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been playing Starmade for about two* years now, on and off. It started out as this small block-based building game with a few unrefined ideas, and has since grown into something much better.The Devs are very active and work with the community. They take lots of community input, and even have representatives from the community to help them understand what the community wants. Starmade is continuously being updated, and appears that it is just going to get better from here on out.The game revolves around building ships and flying around in them, and the tools that the developers have given us are fairly simple, but have plenty of depth.Systems for ship building have been largely implemented, and work beautifully together, from the docking system to the armor system, the logic system to the weapon system. A single block might give a defensive or offensive bonus, and what is in the game now is plenty to offer many possibilities not just for exterior design, but for function as well.There are systems to build a faction, and to build and command fleets around the galaxy. Pirates spawn throughout the galaxy to fight, and while NPCs are not quite in the game yet, the devs are working furiously to implement them in finer detail.Bugs do arise here and there, as it is early access, but for the most part they're being ironed out as soon as they appear.Overall, Starmade is a solid block-based building game (set in space), with an active staff, and an exciting future.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I would like to start right off by saying I highly recommend this game.The main reason I recommend this game is the devs. The devs seem to be interested with what the community wants and they keep you up to date on what they are working on. Devs like this are what make Early Access games worth it.Another reason is the community. I yet to find one person that is a complete jerk. Also, people seem to make some amazing creations. I find it so entertaining when you finish building a ship that you think is so brilliant and you decide to join a server to show it off to find out someone has made a ship 50x stronger. It's just great to see all of the different ships.These two reasons are what make me love this game better than any game in my Library. But, there are of course problems with it.The biggest problem is the amount of players in servers. A game like this with trillions of galaxies should definately have at least 100 players a server. The problem is you're lucky to see 10 players at a time on a server. This could of course easily be fixed by people getting the game, which I really hope happens.The idea of this game getting popular makes me overjoyed. I would love to see big faction wars between 2 major factions and a bunch of miniature allied factions assisting them. Also, a few huge mother ships sending out a bunch of fighter jets, which can actually happen. This stuff is implemented into the game, the problem is there is no people to join those factions.I would love to see this game get players. It has outstanding potential as long as these devs are able to keep working on it. But, that won't happen if the game gets thrown aside and in my eyes, that would be a tragedy.

number of helpful: 43 of 60 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I was really excited when this came out, and still am in some way. Finally a game where you can control your own designed ship from inside, walking through them, "living" in them like you would in a static base in other survivals.In theory there is nothing stopping you from building huge ships with fully decorated interiors, there simply is no point to it from a gameplay perspective. In fact, there is no gameplay really.Update after update they add things like prettier lighting, new logic blocks, new functionality blocks but they still to this day didnt bother about fundamental things that actually make the game a game.Ship interiors are pretty much useless since you can control all systems from the "core" block. Placement of thrusters or even weapons can be pretty much random since own projectiles can pass through your ship so you can effectively place them inside. Center of mass and center of thrust can be disregarded alltogether. In the end you see a lot of cubes flying around that consist of randomly mashed together system blocks since there seems to be no real benefit from carefully planning a nice looking ship design. Sound, as you may think of as a given, does not really work. Homebases and everything docked to them are invulnerable and since there is not much need for more than your homebase, you cant even raid other people. Basically all the game offers right now is mining blocks to build a bigger miner to then mine more blocks.It may be early access and the devs surely were not sleeping but I have to say they are investing their time and effort into the wrong direction. Until that changes we are stuck with a voxel ship designer tool ( thats right, not a game ). The fact that most MP servers are empty - if you can find a populated one with good ping in the first place that is - suggests that I am not the only one who finds the current state of the game disappointing.I really want to like it and wish them well but right now, nuh uh. Cant recommend it.

number of helpful: 29 of 36 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ever seen this really cool spaceship in a movie or another video game and said, "I wish I could fly that"?Ever wanted to cruise the stars in a gigantic space whale?Get on board my miniature B2 bomber, bro.  In. Space.  Starmade lets you do all this.  It lets you do anything.  The limit is up to your computer's processing power, your imagination, and (as always) patience.  It's a survival game, inside a sandbox, wrapped inside a space shooter, topped with jump drives and Stargates.  I've been playing this game for a year now, off and on, but it always, ALWAYS pulls me back for more.  Now that the updates are flying thick and fast, I'm confident you'll be entertained and enthralled just like the rest of us sci-fi junkies.Don't be intimidated by the initial learning curve.  Head to StarmadeDock.net, hit the forums, look into the Community Content section.  The game is way more fun with other players, even when building in single-player.Think Space Engineers is better?Does Space Engineers have a 700 meter Executor-class Super Star Destroyer? What about all those 1000m cap ships that I see flying around on some of Starmade's MP servers?  Starmade trades the realism and feel of Space Engineers for more and bigger ships.  It's a trade that puts it light-years beyond SE, in my opinion.Did I mention we have Stargates?--Ender

You can build space stations too and even colonize planets for yourself or your faction or if you like you can planet-crack them for a valuable resources if harvesting asteroids is not enough for you.If you preffer PvP its not a problem, this game has a really extended weapon system. Combat system might be a little bit unbalaced but hey its still beta testing.Thats all, worth a buy if you like to socialize or roleplay with the people. Or like me you like to build stuff.Engange~

number of helpful: 17 of 18 people (94%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Alright, after playing this for 116 hours I thought I'd share my view of this game. So first, yes I know this is an early access title, but the tutorial kinda' sucks to me. I was still clueless on what to do afterwards, but perhaps maybe I'm just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, idk. The game feels a bit empty with nothing to do, but I wasn't expecting much considering it's an early access title. The reason I've been playing so long was simply out of sheer excitement to keep building onto my ship, and even try to make a little mech or something haha (it's extremely time consuming). It's strangely addicting. It's a sandbox space sim where you start off with nothing but a few things in your inventory. You have a ship core, you hit the X key to create a new ship, name it, and then you build onto it with parts, etc. To make stuff you need to mine of course, so you go out in space and find asteroids or planets and mine them. After you mine and get resources, you need to make factories in order to make stuff with what you mined. Pretty simple, like most crafting games. You can build ships, bases, create factions, you can claim solar systems and make them your faction territory, you can go and fight pirates and destroy their bases. But thats really all there is to it (or at least from what I've seen). With that being said, I think this game was aimed more at multiplayer. It's not a bad game, just wish it didn't take me 100 years to figure out what to do when I first started playing. And also, the pirate stations seem to be there to troll you, as you cannot mine them after you take them out, instead you have to pay an exorbitant amount of money to repair them (15mil), which is really silly to me and kinda defeats the purpose. Idk why the devs did that. Without the help of guides and YouTube videos, i'd be lost and wouldn't have played as long as I did. I do recommend this though, I can't sit here and act like it wasn't fun. Just understand that it's early access, it has bugs, and still needs a lot of work.

content:

Early Access Review
								Finally this amazing game has made it to Steam!This game is amazing to play with some friends and not only create fleets of handbuilt ships (that you create block by block, system by system) but planetary headquaters, massive space stations, and deep space mining platforms.There are plenty of ways to play this game, with the amount of freedom given to the players. Massive PvP battles, solo merchant trade route stuff, pirate hunter, miner, ship builder, etc. Hell, even just exploring the massive galaxy is fun. It's full of planets, asteroids, and other neat things like pirate bases and space stations.I've been playing Starmade for a very long time and the developer never ceases to amaze me. He practically single handedly has created the best space sandbox to date and continually improves it more and more. I've never seen any game receive as much love as this one.As long as you're not turned off by the voxel based engine there is just so much to love here. Even it's weakest elements are usually better fleshed out than comparable games. Just give it a try and if you like it support this awesome developers!

								Adore this game. Despite all its flaws, there's something about this game that keeps me playing. content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have a Dell XPS Laptop which has two video processors, one is the onboard Intel video that it uses when it is on battery power (low power) and the other is an nVidia GT540M (for full AC adapter power). I have configured StarMade (and Java) to run on the nVidia card (just like I do with all my other games including Minecraft) using the nVidia Control Panel. The nVidia card has the latest drivers. I also have the latest version of Java 8.25 64 bit. OS is Windows 7. To be perfectly honest I never use the Intel onboard video unless I am using MS Office or something simple like that because it is just plain aweful with 3d games. Nonetheless, my onboard Intel video has the latest driver available from Dell for my specific laptop.The game does not cooperate with my nVidia control panel, and so the only way I could get it to run was to make my nVidia card as primary video on my laptop always, thus by-passing the nVidia Optimus controls.Changing review to "Tentatively Recommend"

								As I am the Trashman I do enjoy myself some trash, but I am so very dissapointed, it is a wonderful game with very solid mechanics and although that the game has its moments, e.g. lag around planets, asteroids in multiplayer becoming the gods of the realm and a few other things that aren't notable.One issue I have found myself is that when a construct is damaged, it will never be repairable unless you go ahead and do it yourself, now as an avid fan of From The Depths and how it plays, I really see how starmade could benefit from this, even if it requires you to have a shipyard to repair it from, it would become alot more enjoyable and easier to manage large fleets.If you are looking to play this game and you enjoy the "Build your own destiny" kind of things, this will be the game for you, and if you have played EVE online you will find that it is quite similar, set galaxy sizes, your own shops and limited rescoures, warp gates and exploration. Now this may not seem EVE like but when you get to playing it and getting closer to the end game, you will find yourself managing larger and larger scale things, fleets, planets and even wars against others.I have played this for years now and have seen it go through many changes, and it just keeps getting better, and good luck Schema with the development!
